PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987/88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts for inquiry and report by 15 May 1991:

(a) the cost to the Commonwealth, amounting to more than $1m, of the actions of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Australian Customs Service in fulfilling their administrative responsibilities in the handling of the failed prosecution of Midford Paramount Pty Ltd;

(b) the methods of operation of the Australian Customs Service in preparation and conduct of prosecutions and settlements and, in particular, their actions throughout the preparation, prosecution and settlement of the Midford Paramount Pty Ltd case, including the reasons for the Director of Public Prosecutions' discontinuance of the prosecution;
(c) the practice, propriety and method of the Australian Customs Service of gathering evidence for prosecutions and dealing with the public in the course of such investigations;

(d) the actions of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and successive Ministers responsible for Customs in addressing the propriety of administrative actions within the Industry, Technology and Commerce portfolio and the Australian Customs Service, in particular; and

(e) need for effective definition of the lines of ministerial control of the Australian Customs Service and, in particular, the actions of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in oversighting successive Ministers responsible for Customs in relation to the operations of the Australian Customs Service.
As I have read out paragraphs (a), (d) and (e) in amending the motion, I seek to reiterate paragraphs (b) and (c) so that we can address those in this debate. Paragraph (b) reads:

the methods of operation of the Australian Customs Service in preparation and conduct of prosecutions and settlements and, in particular, their actions throughout the preparation, prosecution and settlement of the Midford Paramount Pty Ltd case, including the reasons for the Director of Public Prosecutions' discontinuance of the prosecution.
Paragraph (c) reads:
the practice, propriety and method of the Australian Customs Service of gathering evidence for prosecutions and dealing with the public in the course of such investigations.

This matter became of particular concern to those of us who were attending the Estimates Committee, and those members of the general public who have subsequently read Hansard and shared the concern that was raised by the Committee. It was established in the Estimates Committee that the case of Midford Paramount, which had been investigated by the Customs Service and prosecuted by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), failed because the prosecution relied upon the statement of one Dr Fitzpatrick, an officer of DITAC, who made a statement that the conditions attached to the quota that had been granted to Midford Paramount had, indeed, been breached. Magistrate Falzon, in his summation, discredited the evidence of Dr Fitzpatrick totally, saying that an air of cover-up permeated the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce.

The matter is of considerable concern as the amount of money involved in terms of cost to the Commonwealth in investigation and prosecution, and in terms of damage suffered by the company against which the action was taken, and subsequent settlements being a cost both to the company and to the Commonwealth, need never have arisen if DITAC had carried out its duty in a proper manner.

Dr Fitzpatrick, when asked during his evidence to the Estimates Committee whether he had searched personally, or had asked that any of his officers search personally, for the original documents sourcing the quota, answered that he had not. Yet in evidence, in his sworn statement, he cited this as being one of a series of similar cases and then had to admit in cross-examination that there was, indeed, no precedent.

One of the other reasons why it is important that this matter be thoroughly investigated is that during the entire Estimates hearings the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) said he had no knowledge of this case at all until he read about it in an article written by Bruce Jones in the Sun-Herald dated 7 October 1990. This is despite the fact that during the action the defence subpoenaed Cabinet documents from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet; the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet actually attended at the court and objected to the release of those documents; and the magistrate refused to accept that submission and, indeed, published those documents to counsel. This is also despite the fact that the Malaysian Government-and this was reported in Australian newspapers-contemplated taking extradition proceedings against two officers of the Customs Service, namely, officers O'Shaunnessy and Robinson. This is despite the fact that, in answering some of the material on the record the Minister said that, despite these things, he knew nothing of this case until 7 October. Quite frankly, I find that is either unbelievable or, if it is so, it is totally negligent.

The matter is particularly serious as the Law Council of Australia has indicated that the behaviour of the Customs Service in many ways is Elliot Ness-like. I have had subsequent correspondence from Mr David Vos of Coopers and Lybrand enclosing copies of correspondence from Mr Kelly to Mr Vos, where Mr Vos was query- ing the ruling of the Customs Service that, indeed, no person who is not a qualified lawyer may act for a company subject to investigation. In this particular piece of correspondence to Mr Vos, Mr Kelly said:
The ACS is a government agency with a total investigative arm that takes matters through to the court processes.

This statement in the letter dated May 1989 is totally at variance with the evidence that Mr Kelly gave to Estimates that, somehow, it was all the responsibility of the DPP and he really did not know anything about it.

Indeed, if one takes a good look at the record in Hansard, which shows that we took so long to get answers to what would have otherwise have been regarded as fairly simple questions, one sees that Mr Kelly told the Committee on a total of 34 occasions that he did not know the answers to questions that had been asked, including the words, `I do not know' on nine separate occasions. He neglected to bring to the Estimates Committee hearings his records on the issue and on no fewer than 17 occasions told the Committee that his record would have given him the answers had he had it. He suffered from an acute loss of memory. Yet Mr Kelly told us that he respected the position of the Committee to ask questions on a host of issues relating to the Australian Customs Service, and said that is why he was there. He indicated that he had prepared himself to answer questions in the Committee but the evidence in Hansard will show, quite frankly, that, on several occasions, he deliberately did not know the answers where the matter was being dealt with by the Estimates Committee.

It became particularly concerning when, in the subsequent debate on a matter of public importance, I tabled three affidavits. One of those affidavits dealt with the question of just when those Customs officers were in Malaysia. An affidavit sworn by an officer of the DPP said that the officers had left Malaysia on 15 September. Subsequently, the affidavit that I tabled showed that as late as 2.30 in the afternoon on 16 September the officers concerned were still not only in Malaysia but also were seeking to seize further documents-in the words of the Customs Service, to `get them in a voluntary manner'. But, in fact, this included threatening or coercing people in that household to hand over documents.

Subsequent to that, I have received another affidavit from Malaysia sworn by a manager of the hotel where the Customs officers were staying. He was asked to give a copy of the order which had been gained from the High Court of Malaysia at the institution of Midford Paramount itself, not by the Government as the earlier reports had indicated. The order was given to those Customs officers who then, in the words of the person swearing the affidavit, left the hotel in a hurry on the evening of 16 September despite the fact that they were still booked in and were to remain there until 18 September. In a written answer the Customs Service subsequently supplied information to the Estimates Committee that the officers left Malaysia only after they had completed their investigations. It is indeed a sorry tale.

Going to the terms of reference, one of the other important matters to investigate is the manner in which settlement was effected. There are reports that the $800,000 compensation that Mr Strang told us had been paid by way of compensation had not been paid. The evidence seems to be-and this needs to be investigated and substantiated-that the Customs Service said it would forgo another 1,300 prosecutions in terms of settling this issue. There was a withdrawal of an authorisation by the Comptroller-General of Customs to sell the shirts which had been seized in small parcels the day before the auction. Indeed, the shirts were sold to the person against whom the action had been taken as part of a settlement.

This may well be a proper settlement but I think it is important that the nature and the way in which the settlement was conducted is looked at. I understand that the personal private secretary of Mr Beddall, the Minister for Small Business and Customs, could well have been involved in the negotiation of the settlement. The Minister still tells us that he had heard nothing of this case until 7 October 1990 when he read about it in the Sun-Herald.
The fifth term of reference set out in the amended notice of motion, states:

the need for effective definition of the lines of Ministerial control of the Australian Customs Service and, in particular, the actions of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in oversighting successive Ministers responsible for Customs in relation to the operations of the Australian Customs Service.

One further thing that worries me generally about the attitude of the Australian Customs Service is whether it considers it is governed by the law like the rest of us or whether it is above the law. A very worrying letter was written by one Mr Bissaker, who conveniently went overseas on the day of the Estimates hearing. It is not the first time that Mr Bissaker has been unable to attend at Estimates hearings.

TALK.START.PARA: —You conveniently went overseas last week. We appreciated that.

—I thank Senator Faulkner for that interjection. Had we dealt with the report of Estimates Committee A in its proper order-that is, before B, C, D, E and F-we would have been able to deal with this matter while I was here. It was just convenient, I guess, for the Government that Estimates Committee A was dealt with at the end. When I asked for it to be brought on early, the Government subsequently declined to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the point about whether Customs considers itself to be bound by the law or to be above the law. Mr Bissaker, the man who actually released the shirts in the settlement deal because the Comptroller declined to do so, wrote to the Deputy Ombudsman on 12 April 1990. In his letter he dealt with Mr Macdessi's complaints arising from the way in which the conduct of the case was carried out and also with the comments of Magistrate Falzon on 8 February. The letter says:

Mr Macdessi's complaint stems from the summation by Magistrate Paul Falzon on 8 February 1990 at the conclusion of the committal costs hearing between the DPP and Midford. The substance of the Magistrate's summation questions the bona fides of the ACS in proposing prosecution of Midford and the bona fides of the witnesses used to support the prosecution's case.
The Magistrate's summation has been studied carefully. It is his opinion. The ACS does not share his view and in fact strongly disagrees with it.
Is that not wonderful? Here we have a legal judgment and we have the Australian Customs Service saying that it does not accept the rule of law or the decision of the court.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, Senator! Really!

—The Minister, who is sitting at the table, chooses to laugh these matters off. Indeed, I might say that the reason this matter is of such seriousness is that the amiable Minister, who likes to be a fellow who is regarded as having a lot of bonhomie, is a man who chooses to laugh off matters of substance and things which are serious. He has treated this entire matter with an air of contempt. If he thinks that is a suitable way to run a department, I think it is proper that there be an investigation as to whether others might agree with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Bishop's remarks about the contempt with which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has treated this matter. In particular, I was concerned about the contempt with which the Minister treated the matter when it was raised at a meeting of Estimates Committee A. I am sure that we will hear from Senator Button later about how long it took for this matter to be discussed in Estimates Committee A on 12 October. Indeed, it did take a long time for the matter to be discussed in Estimates Committee A on 12 October. SPEECH.PARA: Perusal of the Hansard will show that we spent some time trying to find the answers to the questions which Senator Bishop raised with regard to the investigation of the Midford Paramount Pty Ltd matter. Yet, we were stonewalled all the way by the Minister. The Minister did not want a departmental officer who was sitting in the audience to sit at the table. —As Senator Button knows, it is true that I do a lot of bobsleighing but I probably would not go downhill as fast as he is at the moment. It can be seen from reading the Hansard of Estimates Committee A of 12 October that Mr Strang was sitting directly behind Senator Button and was shaking and nodding his head vigorously. Senator, that is not a matter which relates to the estimates of my portfolio.

Is the gentleman sitting behind you mysterious? Do we know who he is?
Senator Button replied rather smugly:
I do not know, Senator. I am looking at you, I am not looking behind me. I do not have eyes in the back of my head.

Clearly, Senator Button did not want Mr Strang to come to the table; clearly Senator Button was trying to hide the identity of this gentleman; and it was not until we got another eight pages down the track that we actually found out that he was Mr Strang. This matter may have caused a certain degree of humour for Senator Button; it may have titillated his small mind, while we were trying to deal with the weighty matters of how his Department was being run.

Senator Button cannot come into this chamber and accuse those of us who are on Estimates Committee A of wasting committee time because the man who was most responsible for wasting the Committee's time on that particular day was Senator Button. If Mr Strang had been allowed to come to the table to answer the questions that Senator Bishop had put to him, we could have got through the matter much more quickly. Yet now, when we want to refer the matter to the Public Accounts Committee, I think we are going to see that the Minister will oppose the reference to the Public Accounts Committee.

We are going to see yet another attempt by Senator Button to hide all the problems that have arisen with this case, hide all of the irresponsibility that his Department has shown, hide all of the ineptitude and all of the incompetence, to save himself political embarrassment, to save himself the embarrassment of having these facts raised in public. It was clearly a matter of concern and embarrassment to him on 12 October. It is clearly a matter of embarrassment and concern to him today because he refused leave to Senator Bishop to have the motion taken as formal, and therefore we had to suspend Standing Orders.

Clearly, Senator Button has a vested interest in ensuring that this matter of grave public accountability is not referred to the Public Accounts Committee, that there is no further scrutiny, that there is no further analysis of the waste of taxpayers' money litigating a matter that should never have gone to court. Senator Button does not want us to look into all of the apparent deceptions that occurred before Estimates Committee A, he does not want us to look into why departmental officers gave evidence that seems to be so blatantly contradicted by other evidence that Senator Bishop has so ably been able to put together, evidence coming from as far afield as Malaysia.

We have not had any explanation, nor does Senator Button want to give us an explanation, of why departmental officers appear to have left in great haste from Malaysia. He does not seem to want us to analyse why possibly the Malaysian Government or possibly Midford Paramount itself took out an injunction to prevent Australian Customs officers from returning to Australia with certain documents relating to this matter. These are all the matters that Senator Button wants to hide, these are all the matters that Senator Button wants locked away forever in the dark, dim corridors of the Public Service departments, these are all the matters that Senator Button wants never to see the light of day.

We have to ask ourselves: why does Senator Button want to hide from the truth? Why did Senator Button want to prevent Mr Strang from giving evidence at Estimates Committee A? Why does Senator Button want right now for this matter to go away? Why does he not want full and frank accountability of all the actions of his Department? The answer is very simple: Senator Button's Department, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, has acted irresponsibly or negligently or deceitfully, and he, as the Minister heading that Department, is ultimately responsible.

That is the reason why Senator Button does not want these matters to come to the light of day. That is why Senator Button wants to hide behind every possible bushel he can. Suffice to say that we have had a look at the substance of the allegations and, on balance, we have decided that the answers from the Department and from the Minister have not satisfied our concern about the manner in which the Department and the Minister have handled these matters. As a result, the Australian Democrats support this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I might mention that the amendments which occurred this morning were in fact carried out at the insistence of the Australian Democrats because we did not feel that the issue, in being referred to a committee, should be prejudged in this particular manner. In the same way, the Australian Democrats will support the motion which I understand the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is going to move to request that Senator Bishop does not serve on the Public Accounts Committee which will deal with this matter. In view of the fact that Senator Bishop has quite clearly made her position known and has, in my mind, prejudged the issue to a large extent, I believe and the Democrats believe that this is a fair thing to support. It is in these terms-that this matter requires further investigation and thorough investigation, without its being prejudged in this chamber-that the Democrats support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -Senator Bishop has raised a number of serious matters in relation to the Australian Customs Service. Earlier the honourable senator afforded me the courtesy of referring these matters concerning the terms of reference to me as the Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The matters have been canvassed in a number of forums, including the Senate Estimates Committee. Unfortunately, at that Senate Estimates Committee there were a number of unsatisfactory features, particularly the nature of the answers to justifiable questions from honourable senators. For that reason alone I should have thought there would have been a need for some forum to provide a mechanism for a fuller and more detailed inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, there also appears to be sufficient evidence from court proceedings that the prosecution was grossly mismanaged. In addition, we have been given the opportunity of hearing of affidavits which have been forthcoming which could well add further facts, warranting some form of investigation. I will quote from a submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration from a Mr Spanswick, who I understand was former head of the Customs Officers Association. He made the comment that there was a need for a full-scale inquiry into the effectiveness and efficiency of Customs. He believed that a royal commission could properly look at those sorts of issues. He said:

As a result of those inquiries, in my view, we would have some accountability and some new administration of the Service. Again in my view, it would be more appropriate to the needs and requirements of the legislation's administration.

Therefore, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which comprises members of both Houses and of both Government and Opposition, is the appropriate vehicle to pursue this issue in a calm and impartial way. That Committee seeks to ensure efficiency and appropriate stewardship in the discharge of the work of all government departments and utilities on the Australian scene. I support the Senate's reference to that Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few things about the motion. I should perhaps start with Senator O'Chee, who made an impassioned speech about this issue. When I listen to Senator O'Chee speak, I am sometimes reminded of the sonnet of Tennyson's which begins: Break, break, break, on thy cold gray stones, O'Chee, and I would that my tongue could utter the thoughts that arise in me. All sorts of thoughts arise in me when I hear Senator O'Chee speak, when I hear that adolescent, windy rhetoric in which he indulges. As someone who has been here for a long time, let me give Senator O'Chee a bit of advice: if he wants to hitch his wagon to a star, he should not hitch it to Senator Bishop. Let me give him one more bit of advice. The Estimates Committee looking into this issue took 60 hours--
—Sixty-four.

—Sixty - four, and Senator O'Chee was there for a lot of the time. It wasted $200,000 of public servants' time when Senator O'Chee, Senator Bishop and others were there. It reiterated all sorts of unsubstantiated allegations and it was a tale full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. Those opposite should put Senator Michael Baume from the waste watch committee on to Senator Bishop. It was $200,000 worth of public servants' time dealing with unsubstantiated allegations. What happened to Senator O'Chee when this matter was debated in the Parliament last week in the Committee of the Whole, and where was Senator Bishop?
—I was in the chamber.

—Well, the honourable senator said nothing. Where was Senator Bishop? She was overseas on a parliamentary trip, spending more taxpayers' money. That is where Senator Bishop was. She was overseas, not here doing her duties as a senator. She was not here and Senator O'Chee was not here, and they come in here today and make these windy allegations against the Government on this matter.
—Look at the substance.

—That is the truth, which is undeniable in the form of any interjection. I want to move an amendment to the motion. If we look back over the history of the matter, we see that what the taxpayers are being asked to finance in this inquiry is a private indulgence of Senator Bishop.
—Millions of dollars your Department wasted.

—Millions of dollars of my Department's time has been wasted by Senator Bishop. It is no good coming in here with her student law moot rhetoric, making further unsubstantiated allegations in the course of this matter. I accept that some of these matters could be referred to the Public Accounts Committee. I do not mind that; I am not afraid of any inquiry. I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, and that Senator Bishop not participate in any hearing of the Committee on the subject matter of this reference.''

If that is not accepted, the credibility of the Public Accounts Committee must be in question. Senator Bishop sought to amend her motion at the last moment, which we can see if we look at the first draft. I ask the Liberals, the people who are concerned about proprietary and civil liberties, to look at the first draft of Senator Bishop's motion, her private indulgence. Let us look at the quality of that private indulgence and at the wording of her original motion. It condemns people out of hand before the matter has been referred to inquiry by the Public Accounts Committee. She woke up to that at the last moment and went back to her legal textbook, perhaps, or got some advice from one of her advisers. She went back to some semblance of propriety in this matter and sought to change it.

One of the changes Senator Bishop made was, instead of accusing me of failure, to refer to my actions. Well, I am delighted with that because all through the Estimates Committee hearings she was accusing me of inaction. It is a delightful change to have that. If we look at the wording of the original motion, we see right through it in every clause suggestions which prejudge the Australian Customs Service. She seeks to be judge and jury in her own cause-and it is her cause, nobody else's. It is her cause following other causes which she has had in this place. This is now her thing, her launching pad into political success, from the back bench to the front bench, she thinks. Well, I am sorry to disabuse Senator Bishop about that, but if it is her cause, and it is, she cannot sit in judgment on it. That is what she seeks to do by referring this matter to the Public Accounts Committee.

Let me make a few other points. There were 60 hours of hearings on this matter in the Estimates Committee. The Senate, the chamber to which we all belong-and to which all the Liberal senators opposite belong-had the opportunity to debate all this last week. Not one of them did so. I was here waiting for them, but not one got up to speak on the matter. Senator Watson did not get up, Senator O'Chee was not here--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was.

—Or if he was, he did not say boo; he did not say a word. Senator Bishop was not here at all. Not one of them got up when they had the opportunity to deal with this matter in the Committee of the Whole.
—Wrong. I asked questions.
—Oh, some weak, limp-wristed questions that had nothing to do with the issue.
—You had a limp-wristed answer.

—The honourable senator thanked me for the answer. What a limp-wristed, miserable performance it was for something which is produced here today as a cause celebre-a great issue which this lacklustre Liberal Opposition suddenly sees as a goer. The Opposition cannot do anything else in this chamber, but Senator Bishop's private indulgence has to be supported.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop seeks a further inquiry into the Customs Service. I cannot resist inquiries into the Customs Service, if that is what people want. I think the Customs Service is a fine service, but it will make mistakes. If it does make mistakes-and there are allegations of mistakes here-then these are matters which can properly be inquired into by the Public Accounts Committee. I would remind the Senate that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration is already conducting an inquiry into Customs. But that is not enough for Senator Bishop. She wants her own inquiry as well. She wants the great Bishopgate inquiry into the Customs Service as an add-on.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the Buttongate inquiry.

—Let us wait and see, because I recall what Senator Bishop said in the Estimates Committee. Senator Bishop is not very good at asking questions, if she does not mind me telling her. Senator Bishop is very good at making allegations, but not good at asking questions.
—That is why she's on the back bench.

—Of course that is why she is on the back bench: Dr Hewson has some style. Senator Bishop made a lot of allegations, but she is not too good at asking questions. There is already an inquiry into the Customs Service by the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration and now Senator Bishop wants another one. The Australian Democrats, who did not participate in all this farce at the Estimates Committee and who did not participate in the debate on the Estimates in the Committee of the Whole, support it. I understand that, because the Democrats obviously take the view that they support the principle of public inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is also a principle of public administration and public finance; that is to say, the expenditure of taxpayers' money. With one inquiry going already into Customs, we are now going to have another one. This motion is presumably supported by the Liberals, the people who have a waste watch committee, for goodness sake! This second duplicating inquiry is again at taxpayers' expense-costing a lot of money and a lot of time-in order to indulge Senator Bishop with her private fantasies.

If the Opposition wants to do that, then that becomes a matter of public political debate and I will not hesitate to say that this is how the Opposition views public administration and public finance and the expenditure of taxpayers' money.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! Come on!

— `Come on', says Senator Watson. Senator Watson ought to have come on when the debate was here last week, but he did not come on at all. Senator Watson just got Senator Bishop breathing into his shell-pink ear in the Senate and felt that he ought to be loyal to the troops and make a little speech this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: We now will have had, if this motion is passed, two inquiries into Customs; 60 hours of this in Estimates Committee; and a quarter of an hour on this in the Committee of the Whole-when I am waiting here to answer questions and deal with issues-because the relevant Liberals were not here or, in Senator O'Chee's case, not here in his mind: physically present but not here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The Minister, in getting carried away as usual with rhetoric and not substance, has reflected on the standing of a fellow member, Senator O'Chee, and I ask him to withdraw.
—It is nothing worse than I have heard this morning so I do not think that there is any point of order.
—That is my ruling, Senator Crane.
—With respect, Mr Deputy President, the point of order related to the statement that Senator O'Chee was not here in his mind. That is clearly a reflection, and I ask him to withdraw.

—I am not asking Senator Button to withdraw it because I heard Senator O'Chee make a similar claim this morning about Senator Button, and nothing was raised then. I am not upholding the point of order.
—May I ask for clarification? Am I to take it that your ruling means that you will allow a reflection on a fellow senator to remain if you consider it is merely tit for tat?
—I have made my ruling. I call Senator Button.
—It is scarcely a reflection on a senator. Senator O'Chee is quite entitled to waft off and go to sleep in here. A lot of people do.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Button is now suggesting that I was asleep. That is grossly inaccurate. Senator Button knows it is grossly inaccurate. He is making an untrue statement in this chamber and I now request that you ask him to withdraw that statement, which he knows is false.

—On the point of order, Mr Deputy President: my clear recollection of Senator Button's remarks was that Senator O'Chee was entitled to be asleep. I think that is very different to the interpretation of Senator O'Chee.
—I think we are probably splitting straws. I would ask Senator Button to withdraw the statement.
—Withdraw what statement?
—About Senator O'Chee being entitled to be asleep.

—If it is your ruling, Mr Deputy President, that senators are not entitled to be asleep-because that is what it amounts to-it is going to be a tough life. But if you want me to withdraw, with respect, accepting your ruling for perpetuity for senators yet unborn that they are not allowed to sleep in here, then I will, if you think that will facilitate the debate.
—I do think it will facilitate the running of the Senate.

—All right. Let me just recapitulate, first, about the processes of the Senate. We have had an Estimates committee which went for 60 hours, many of those hours on this issue. Estimates committees report to the Senate. When they reported to the Senate, Senator Bishop was not here. Senator O'Chee was here-the silent Senator O'Chee: still the silent night Senator O'Chee-when the Estimates committees were here.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats also said nothing on this particular issue. I set aside a day, anticipating a lot of discussion in the Committee of the Whole. Nothing happened. The matter is now raised today in the context of seeking an inquiry into the Customs Service. There is already one going at public expense. The Liberals, presumably, support this private indulgence of having a second inquiry going at public expense, and I tell those opposite: you will hear about it.

In the Senate on 8 November-the day on which we might have heard all of this stuff from Liberal senators, if they were interested or concerned-Senator Childs, at page 3730 of the Hansard and thereafter, dealt with some of these issues, and about the wildness and the unsubstantiated nature of the allegations made in the course of the Estimates Committee.

So far as Senator Bishop's motion is concerned, I just repeat that it prejudges every issue which could go before the Public Accounts Committee. She tried to change it this morning. It still prejudges every issue which should properly go before the Public Accounts Committee. I happen to be an old-fashioned lawyer who believes that people should not be judge and jury in their own cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great principle.

—It is a great principle. This is Senator Bishop's cause and I understand that she has a law degree. If she had one inkling of understanding of that great principle, which was espoused by people whom I politically disliked-such people as Sir Robert Menzies, great folk heroes of the Liberal Party-she would voluntarily say, `Let us have an inquiry by the Public Accounts Committee, but I do not want to be part of it'. Senator Bishop would say that, but she is not big enough to do so. That is the problem and that is why I moved the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bishop is just not big enough to say that, because what she is seeking from this is publicity, limelight, a launching pad-all that sort of stuff. If Senator Bishop understood the principles she pretends to espouse, she would have nothing to do with the Public Accounts Committee inquiry. Having said that, I do not resist the inquiry at all. I am happy with it and I look forward to the outcome, but I want that outcome to be fair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly in this debate because there are matters which I think should be put on the record and which certainly cause me and those on my side of the chamber great concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I think Senator Button has indulged in a familiar parliamentary tactic of attempting to turn a serious matter into a joke. It is not a joke. On the face of it, the reference to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is for an inquiry and report into the cost to the Commonwealth, amounting to more than $1m, of the actions of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Australian Customs Service in fulfilling their administrative responsibilities in the handling of a particular failed prosecution. I can think of no more appropriate body within this Parliament to investigate allegations of this type than the Public Accounts Committee. In fact, that seems to me to be the proper course of action that should be adopted. The fact that a considerable amount of time was taken on the same issue in the Estimates Committee seems to me to be irrelevant. The Estimates Committee has a particular function and particular types of witness before it, that is, principally the Minister and those public servants to whom the Minister wishes to refer. An investigation into a matter like this may well require the calling of particular witnesses and may well require the powers given to the Public Accounts Committee under its legislation to get to the bottom of these allegations to ensure that the eventual findings are well based on fact. The Public Accounts Committee has been set up as the appropriate mechanism for dealing with these matters. It has a good record and a good standing, and its independence is unchallenged. Therefore I do not understand at all the objection of the Government to the reference itself.

That really was not the reason I wanted to speak. I wanted to speak about the amendment of Senator Button which seeks to exclude a particular senator from participating in the inquiry, that is, a senator who was appointed by this House as its representative and in this instance as a representative of the Opposition upon this committee. The advice I have received is that the exercise we are going through is unprecedented and, although it may be within the powers of the chamber, when one has the numbers, one can do anything. That does not mean it is right but when the Government has the numbers--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying it is wrong?
—Yes, I am saying that. I think the Government is establishing a very dangerous precedent.
—Oh, yes.
—Oh, yes, make a joke of that as well. The Government has made a joke of the recession and it is making a joke of the reference.
—I am making a joke of you.

—Oh, yes. Let us project this matter one step further into a situation where one party has the majority in this chamber. Anyone would think it would be highly inappropriate if that one party started to dictate to the other side of the chamber which senators it was prepared to have on particular inquiries and which it was not. That is what is being proposed to the Senate today. Everyone comes into this place with certain bias. If one did not have bias, one would not be here and would not be participating within a particular party. I can think of so many occasions when it may be argued that senators have raised a matter of public interest or has sought an inquiry into a particular matter because it was one of their interests. It might be their speciality or area of expertise or it may be they have had a long involvement in that area. There is nothing unusual in that at all. But to prejudge that that person will prejudiced in the outcome of the inquiry seems to me to be totally inappropriate. There is no basis on which it can be done fairly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Accounts Committee has operated independently, it has its own internal discipline and it determines who participates in particular inquiries. Rather than allow it to do that in this instance, the Government has joined with the Australian Democrats and has taken this highly undesirable step of voting to exclude a particular senator from participation in the inquiry. I voice a protest in opposition to what is occurring today. I believe it creates a bad precedent for this chamber and one which is capable of being used again in the future in undesirable ways. That will occur because the Government has the numbers, but I regret that Senator Button, who has clearly allowed Senator Bishop to get under his skin in this matter, is now acting in a way which will create an undesirable precedent that will last for a long time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Hill has raised this very important issue because I was going to raise it myself and speak to the amendment moved by Senator Button. Following Senator Button's speech through to its logical conclusion, one finds that it was all about reasons for voting against the referral. He did not advance any principled argument in support of the amendment that would exclude one member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts from sitting on that committee for the purposes of this reference. As Senator Hill said, this is unprecedented. Mr Deputy President, I think it is 15 years ago either today or tomorrow since you and I were elected to this place. In that time I have not heard even a suggestion that an individual senator should be excluded from a parliamentary committee. I recall a number of issues which were raised and I will raise one of them here for the purposes of consideration by Senator Button and the Opposition because I believe that what he is doing will create a precedent. I do not know whose suggestion it was. If it was suggested by the Australian Democrats, they ought to think about it, too.

SPEECH.PARA: If another government comes to power after the next election, we may find that this precedent may be followed then. What happened, for example, when the Viner industrial legislation came forward to this chamber in 1981? A Senate Select Committee was established to inquire into that legislation. I was appointed the chairman of that industrial legislation committee. Clearly I had a view of the trade union movement which had been ingrained in me over many years. I was actively involved in the trade union movement. There was no suggestion that I should be excluded from being a member of that Select Committee. On the contrary, I was eventually appointed chairman of that committee and Senator Button was a member of it, as were a number of other senators. In the event of this occurring again, as it most likely will occur, would the then Government, if it were a conservative Government, using this precedent say that Harradine should not be on that committee or that somebody else should not be on it? I think we would be establishing a precedent and I appeal to Senator Button to reconsider that. If his arguments are strong enough in respect of the matter not going before the committee, then he can vote against the reference to the committee entirely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will withdraw the amendment which I moved. This is not because of Senator Harradine's speech. I had hoped to provoke Senator Bishop into an honourable course of conduct by moving the amendment. As I have not been able to do so, I seek leave to withdraw it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-It is with some sense of disappointment that I rise to speak to the debate that has ensued since my moving the motion. I notice that Senator Button appears to have left the chamber. Senator Button, instead of addressing any of the issues of substance, attempted to turn this from a debate on serious matters to a debate of some frivolity-this has become a technique which we are well used to in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give an example of how this practice is not unusual but something with which we perpetually live. The sort of flippancy that we have just heard-and, indeed, Senator Button, who one could call the Minister for sound and fury, adopted his own private indulgences as distinct from what he alleged were mine in dealing with a matter of substance-is recorded in the Hansard of 12 October 1990, commencing at page 636. I asked a question about Mr Strang, the man who Senator Button, for a long time, refused to even turn around and look at so that we could identify who he was. He became the mystery man. I asked:
Did Mr Strang know about the request for the return of documents from the Malaysian Government?

At that stage we were going through the farce of Senator Button not allowing Mr Strang to come to the table and answer in his own right. He was insisting that he take the information from Mr Strang and that he would then answer on his behalf. Senator Button then answered:
No.

Let me turn to page 647. If we are in the business of timing things we can estimate that each one of these pages covers five minutes of evidence. So it took us one hour and 10 minutes to get an answer to this question that I asked Mr Strang:
When did you first become aware of the fact that they had the documents?
Mr Strang replied:
I was in Malaysia at the time.

That is exactly the sort of obstruction, evasion and contempt that went on during the entire 58, 60 or 64 hours-depending on how one likes to add it up; we have had three different versions from the Government.

The long and the short of it is that anybody who chooses to read the record can find example upon example of how it took an hour and 10 minutes to reach the true answer as distinct from the initial answer which one could be uncharitable enough to say misled the Committee. When I say that I would have liked Senator Button to deal with the substantial issues, instead of giving sarcastic side references-as is his norm-I think I can be pardoned for feeling some anger.

I suppose I could also be flattered. I could be flattered by Senator Button's attempt to exclude me from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts hearings. I could be flattered by the way in which the Estimates A Committee report was dealt with. For some curious reason, it was determined that the report of Estimates Committee A would not be dealt with before the reports of Estimates Committees B, C, D and F, but, in fact, contrary to the alphabet, would come at the end. I did ask, because I found this curious, that we challenge that arrangement. I subsequently asked, after we had commenced our consideration of the report of Estimates Committee B, that the Estimates Committee A report be brought on before Estimates Committee C report. I was told that, yes, we could do that.

I wrote to the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, and advised him that I had to go to China as part of a trade mission-a trade mission which was attempting to salvage our precarious wool trade, among other things, on the Chinese market; a fairly important issue. Immediately after I wrote the letter to Senator Bolkus advising him of the dates that I would be away, guess what?-the Government said that it would not bring the report of Estimates Committee A up the list; it would stay at the bottom. My private information yesterday was that everybody thought that they were off the hook.

I suppose I could be flattered. As a member of the Opposition, I am outnumbered on all occasions by members of Government who sit on the Public Accounts Committee. I might say that they carry out their duties with great honour and distinction. I would not want, for one moment, to reflect upon the integrity of the way that members of that Committee carry out their responsibilities. All of us share the attitude that the interests of the Parliament and the people must be served first and foremost, as indeed we stated categorically in our report The Auditor-General: ally of the people and Parliament. I suppose I could be very flattered that Senator Button felt that I should be denied the opportunity to ask questions. I am very glad that he did not reflect on the Committee or the work that it carries out.

I also add that in the reservation to the report of Estimates Committee A we foreshadowed that we would be moving to refer this matter to the Public Accounts Committee. I do not know whether the Government thought, and Senator Button thought in particular, that by my not being here when the matter was dealt with in the committee stage of the Appropriation Bills somehow we would not be moving that foreshadowed motion. I cannot see inside his mind. But I do know that Senator Button refused in this Parliament today to deal with any matter of substance at all. Instead of saying, `I am concerned about this issue or that issue and I have an answer here or an answer there', he simply made a personality slur.

Indeed, his only reference to this matter was a speech made by Senator Childs in the early part of November in which Senator Childs made the quite remarkable statement that we had the choice of believing Australian Customs Service officers or people in another country. I subsequently asked a question of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, about the implication that somehow the word of an Australian Customs officer was better than that of a Malaysian who had sworn an affidavit. Senator Evans had the good grace to say, no, he did not agree with that implication.

By referring this matter to the Public Accounts Committee for further investigation-and I might say that as a member of that Committee, I go into this investigation looking for answers and not looking, in any way, for anything else-perhaps we will find the truth and perhaps the taxpayer, in the end, will find out why at least $1m of investigation money was wasted and why certain methods of investigation were pursued. In the final analysis, we may be able to repair the damage that has been done to our relationship with the Malaysian Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to restate, in clearer terms, the Government's position in relation to an amendment moved by Senator Patterson, but I notice that the Australian Democrats are seeking the call. I might defer to the Democrats in order to save the time of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter being discussed when the consideration of the Committee was suspended the other evening was an Opposition amendment in relation to the disclosure of statistical information. If that statistical information was of a sufficient degree of specificity, the manufacturer of the pharmaceutical benefits could be identified through those statistics.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that at the point of the suspension I was asking Senator Tate what reason the Government had for introducing this amending clause, because we were not persuaded one way or the other and we sought some assurance as to the reasons for its introduction. We reported progress, which was fortunate, because there seemed to be some confusion as to why the amendment was being introduced. Since the other evening I have had occasion to speak to Dr David Henry of Newcastle, who provided a very precise example as to why the particular clause should be inserted in the legislation and, therefore, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting the amendment.

Dr David Henry is a pharmacologist who has done a considerable amount of work in comparing the prescription rates of particular drugs which could be used for the same purpose. The example he gave to me was of two drugs, clofibrate and cholestyramine, both of which are used for the reduction of blood cholesterol. Dr Henry had observed that the drug clofibrate had increased in its rate of prescription very considerably, and that the drug clofibrate was the one of the two against which considerable queries had arisen regarding its safety.

He wished to publish those statistics which had come to him via quite legitimate sources as a member of a committee which looks at these things. But at that stage he was prevented from publishing this information for the benefit of general practitioners and others who may, through that publication, be steered towards prescribing what he and many others perceive to be the less dangerous alternative; namely, cholestyramine. He went on to describe to me a number of examples of situations such as this where, through his membership of the committee, he had become aware of situations in which it was important that precise statistical information be given to general practitioners, and that he would have been prevented from publishing that information if that information was sufficiently precise to have led to the identification of the manufacturers.

He also went on to point out to me that the manufacturers have access to pretty good information already through their own sources and that this really goes one step further. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly want to congratulate the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) on his very sensible decision to accept the proposition that the Opposition has been maintaining for quite some time, that is, that there should not be age discrimination. The incredible logical flaw and the intellectual hollowness in the Democrats' position-they are saved from further embarrassment in expressing their extraordinary attitude by the good sense of the Minister in this case-are exposed by the fact that the National Library of Australia, the Australian National Gallery and the National Museum of Australia have no age provisions and are managing to survive without the world falling in. The Australian Democrats have chosen in the past to accept what had been the Government's view that, in additional legislation, it should follow the course set by those bodies that do have a 65 year age limit, such as the Institute of Sport and the Australian Tourist Commission, and not follow the course set by the other bodies I have mentioned, along with the Australian Heritage Commission, which one would think is timeless, and it is. Do we keep extending the range of this discrimination or do we say, `No, we will block that discrimination'? Our objective was to bring forward, to hasten, this review instead of allowing it to drift on. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer very briefly to the schedule to the Bill, which deals with the consequential and minor amendments to the Child Care Act 1972. The schedule seeks to omit from the definition of `child care' in subsection 4 (1) of the Child Care Act the words `during the day'. A statement made on page 258 of the explanatory notes of the Department of Community Services and Health to Estimates Committee C refers to the primary objective of the child-care program being `to support work force participation by families with young children', with a secondary objective of supporting `non- working parents'.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a question as to whether the ultimate result of those objectives is to facilitate the higher participation rate of mothers in the paid work force at a time when jobs are just not available for mothers in the paid work force, or for many fathers, or for young people. It also raises the question as to whether the Government would explore ways of assisting mothers of young children who wish to raise their children on a full time basis by helping them to cope with economic pressure. It raises the question as to whether, in fact, the thrust of this whole program is to limit ultimately the number of child-care places for mothers who choose to be almost full time at home, so that they can use occasional child-care for various situations, including appointments and shopping, and for other reasons.

It seems to me that the priorities of the Government need looking at. The Federal Treasurer, Mr Keating, boasted the year before last that we now had a situation where families had two and sometimes three incomes. That is nothing to boast about. I thought that wage rates and the taxation regime of a government should ensure that a family could exist on one income. I would hate to see this measure go through without questioning the Government's policies, and questioning them very seriously, as to the end result. This leads me to the provision in the original Child Care Act which deals with research grants. Section 13 of that Act provides that:
(1) The Minister may, in the discretion of the Minister . . . make a grant of moneys to any person for purposes of or relating to:
(a) research in child care and related matters; and
(b) the initiation and development of methods of child care.

The schedule to the Bill that is currently before us omits the words `in the discretion of the Minister'. It also omits the words `make a grant of moneys' and substitutes `approve the making of a grant'. I am not sure precisely what that means, whether there is difference in the meaning at all. But, clearly, the grant should be made to people and organisations who do not have a vested interest in the child-care industry.

Attention should be given to some very thoughtful papers that have been produced on the long term effect of child-care. I refer to an article in the Australian of 25 October 1990 by Barry Maley, a Senior Fellow at the Centre for Independent Studies and a Visiting Fellow in the Faculty of Commerce at the University of New South Wales. That article had this to say:
The Federal Government's recent initiative expanding formal, tax-subsidised childcare raises many issues of equity and economic efficiency.

Is it fair, for example, that the majority of those who will take advantage of the subsidy are two-income families who will be subsidised, in effect, by the taxes from single-income families? Is it fair that highly-educated mothers will tend to profit more than less-educated or less-employable mothers?
Taking these two things together, formal, subsidised childcare begins to look like another middle-class welfare rip-off at the expense of stay-at-home mothers and their worker husbands.

But just as important as the equity issues are the economic efficiency outcomes and, more deeply, the long-term social and human consequences of a trend to put preschool infants into care by professionals for several hours a day, five days a week, in order to help both parents work full-time.

All parents, at one time or another, need someone to look after their infants for several hours at a time or, more regularly, for a few hours a day several days a week to allow them to work part-time or to do other things.
Usually they call upon members of their own families, or friends or casual helpers. This is predominantly `informal', unsubsidised care (at least until recently), and there is nothing new about this.

What is new is the increasing demand for subsidised, formal, professional care for very young children for greatly extended periods by the increasing army of young married women re-entering or staying in the workforce full-time after the birth of a child.
We are witnessing a strong social shift that is quantitatively and qualitatively different from the recent past. It is time to assess what it means.

I am not sure what the amendments to the original Act meant about research grants in that particular area. Perhaps the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), could tell me what, if anything, they mean. But I feel that the Government itself should examine in depth the effect that its economic policies are having, including its high interest rates policies which have forced many persons into the paid work force who otherwise would prefer to not be there and who have more important things to be doing-policies which create great pressures on single-income families. But that is not the worst situation. The worst is the effect it is going to have on the children. As Mr Maley says:

Can we expect strangers, no matter how professional, to bring to the care of their charges for several hours a day, five days a week, the kind of emotional involvement and the capacity for self-sacrifice that has been shown, over and over again, to be the essential distinguishing feature of the natural parents or close relatives?
He goes on to say, and this is my final quotation:
Under the name of `attachment theory', a great deal of evidence has accumulated in recent years to show that secure attachment to the mother is vital to the benign development of an infant.

When it is firmly established, secure exploration of the world and anxiety-free learning take place. But when the bond is broken, or not firmly fixed in the first place, anxiety and even grief and depression follow, undermining the potential for effective learning and anxiety-free development.
I believe that it is very important for the Government to take those factors into consideration in pursuing the policy that is currently being pursued.

The Australian Democrats are committed to what we believe is a much better solution to these sorts of problems, particularly the issue of poverty traps, which Senator Harradine raised. Our solution is to provide every citizen in Australia with what we call a national support income. That would be income provided by the Government as of right to every citizen irrespective of income, not subject to the means test and not subject therefore to the enormous bureaucratic complexities to which Senator Harradine has drawn our attention. The income which a person then chose to earn over and above that would simply be income on top of that national support income and the total income would be subject to taxation. Therefore, most of the national support income paid to those in our community who have high incomes would go back immediately by way of tax. However, people would be in a much freer position to choose how they would spend that money on a whole range of social services and would immediately avoid the problem of poverty traps because the income earned would be money on top and would not be subject to a means test. It would also have the enormous advantage of removing the very complex bureaucratic processes which are currently necessary and which in themselves provide some of the problems to which Senator Harradine has drawn our attention.

The Australian Democrats believe that would substantially simplify a large amount of the social justice and social welfare legislation which passes through this Parliament and would also leave the citizens of Australia in a much freer situation to make their decisions about the way in which they want their money spent for their welfare and benefit and for the welfare and benefit of their children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 deals with substantive matters, it completely fails Australia. The legislation fails not by what it contains, but by what it omits.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill makes a number of technical amendments to several Acts. It is not my intention to deal with all these amendments, but simply to concentrate on the major amendments relating to this legislation, which are about the position of certain members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the most important part of the legislation, the compliance provisions in the Industrial Relations Act, so far as employers are concerned in relation to contributions to superannuation funds on behalf of their employees.

This legislation does absolutely nothing about the more important broader issue of general compliance measures. That is why the Opposition in the committee stage of this debate will seek to amend this Bill by inserting into it provisions which were first introduced in the form of a private member's Bill late in 1987 by Senator Chaney, as he then was, and subsequently by myself as amendments to the then new Industrial Relations Bill 1988 to vest in the Industrial Relations Commission and also in the Federal Court of Australia certain injunctive powers in relation to non-compliance with awards by organisations and individuals.

The Opposition will not oppose the Bill as a whole, but it certainly will seek to have those amendments passed. The Opposition will obviously seek the support of the Senate and particularly the Australian Democrats for these amendments. We will not oppose the Bill as a whole because we accept that, if it is the law of Australia that superannuation be part of the award fixing mechanism, it is only fair and proper that the law sees to it that people who are entitled to and are awarded superannuation benefits should receive those benefits. To the extent that any employer is falling short of his or her obligation to make those payments, it is only fair and reasonable that proper restitution be available to employees.

However, it is in the spirit of that award compliance that the Opposition believes that the other side of the ledger should be considered. We have heard a lot of talk in recent days about the need for a level playing field across a whole range of issues but particularly economic issues. It is also very important that the level playing field apply in the area of industrial relations. The Opposition takes the view that, if it is good enough to oblige employers to stick to the terms of an award and some constraint is placed upon them should they fail to do so, it is only fair and reasonable that the same approach apply in relation to organisations.

This Bill, as did earlier industrial relations legislation put forward by the Government, completely fails to remedy the impotence of the Industrial Relations Commission to enforce its decisions. Let me remind the Senate that as long ago as 14 May 1987, when the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, introduced the first Industrial Relations Bill, which was to replace the old conciliation and arbitration legislation with an updated Bill, he described compliance provisions as an essential element of the industrial relations system.

He went on to point out that the current bans clause procedure, which was in operation at that time, was disreputable and substantially moribund. In that original 1987 Bill penalties tougher than those under the existing Conciliation and Arbitration Act were to be imposed. They were to include fines, alteration to an organisation's eligibility rules to exclude specified groups from membership and the imposition of conditions as to future industrial conduct. A serious continuing breach of direction by an organisation or its members would lead to deregistration.

However, when this Government shelved that Bill for its own electoral convenience when it called the unnecessarily early 1987 election it also dropped these tougher compliance provisions. The Government subsequently blamed employers for that, but it was quite obvious that it was the pressure of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) which forced the Government to back down on that issue. The then President of the ACTU, now a member of this Parliament and, indeed, a Minister in this Hawke Labor Government, Simon Crean, was quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 17 August as saying:
They-
they being the Government of course-
can still introduce a Bill but it will have to be one which does not do anything on compliance.

In the same month the then ACTU Assistant Secretary, Mr Gary Weaven, claimed that the shelved Bill should be scrapped because it held `little comfort for the unions'. If this does not spell out the intentions of the ACTU I certainly do not know what does.

Moreover, many employer groups, including the Confederation of Australian Industry, expressed opposition to the original Bill on the grounds, among others, that it did not go far enough to strengthen enforcement provisions. The end result was that, in the subsequent legislation which the Government introduced and which was passed as the Industrial Relations Act in 1988, the Commission was nominally given a great number of powers but it had no effective enforcement mechanisms to back up those powers except, oddly enough, against unions which declined to amalgamate, which is the subject of another piece of legislation which will be debated later today.

Although this legislation which we are now debating provides a greater level of enforcement against employers who fail to meet the superannuation requirements of awards, it still does absolutely nothing to level the playing field and provide adequate enforcement provisions to ensure that employees and unions, in particular, comply with the directions of the Industrial Relations Commission.

The Liberal and National parties believe that employers and employees should be free to make their own agreements on employment conditions and wages. That is the policy that we will introduce when we are elected to government in a couple of years time. However, while we still have a system of conciliation and arbitration as the central feature of our industrial relations system in Australia there must be provisions to ensure that parties who are subject to Commission rulings comply with its directions. So if our amendments to this legislation are not supported in this chamber today, we will certainly enact legislation when we achieve government to ensure that there are effective sanctions for those who fail to comply with the decisions and orders of the Commission. This will enable the Commission to issue directions to stop or prevent industrial action and it will also ensure that such directions would be enforceable by injunctions issued by the Federal Court of Australia. Failure to comply with those injunctions would indeed constitute contempt of court.

In addition, any person who suffers damage or loss as a result of industrial action which is in breach of a direction would be able to sue the responsible organisation for damages in the Federal Court. We would also review all penalties in the Act to ensure that they are appropriate and effective. Under the current legislation, unions, or employers for that matter, are free to flout those decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission with impunity. Only with enforceable and equitable compliance provisions can an industrial relations system, involving arbitration, operate fairly and effectively. It is for those reasons that, in the Committee stage of this debate, we will be moving those amendments yet again and we hope that on this occasion they will achieve the support of the Senate. It is important generally, but most particularly in a time of economic downturn and turbulence, that the directions and decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission are complied with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Defence to the Prime Minister's statement yesterday on the Gulf and also to some remarks he made in an interview last night on the 7.30 Report. My question refers to the nature and extent of Australian command of the naval forces in the Gulf. Can the Minister explain exactly what it is that the Prime Minister's statement has committed Australian forces to do? Are our forces now committed to fight in a military operation against Iraq if such breaks out, or is it that the decision to fight as opposed to just preparing for it will also require Government approval at a later date?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The current position is that the ships have been deployed to the northern Gulf. There they will join the allied task force, basically consisting at that end of the Gulf of British, Canadian, United States and Australian forces. As said before, the ships will be under our National Command. They will be under task force commander operational control. We will be issuing rules of engagement and operational procedures.

ANSWER.PARA: As to an absolutely definitive commitment that in every possible circumstance those ships would automatically be committed to war, the answer is no. That is a decision the Australian Government would have to make. As allies, one would expect some forewarning. But I would have to say also that it would be exceptional circumstances if Australian ships were not there and were not involved in any conflict-only the most exceptional circumstances. I do not want to detail those, but I think the Senate can imagine some of the more bizarre circumstances that I would rule out. That would mean, of course, very tight time lines. That is, I suppose, what government is for-to make those decisions under those time lines.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Did the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) release its bulletin on industrial disputation for Australia last week? Do the independent ABS figures show that the consensual approach to industrial relations under the Hawke Government has produced a continuing trend of a low rate of industrial disputation in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 November the Australian Bureau of Statistics released its latest series of industrial disputes statistics in Australia. The series shows a continuing decline in the number of days lost because of disputes and in the incidence of disputes per head.

ANSWER.PARA: For the month of August 1990, 49,000 working days were lost in Australia in 110 disputes. These were the lowest figures for August in any year since 1964. I point out to the Senate that the work force is about 70 per cent larger than it was in 1964; therefore, the per head figures are down around our socks. The number of working days lost for the year ended 1990 was 877,300, which was the lowest year ended August figure since 1967 when the work force was 69 per cent smaller than it is at the moment.

Given the lower rate of disputation, that works out at 137 working days lost per 1,000 in the year to August, which is the lowest figure since the measure was first published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. In particular sectors, the August figure showed that disputes in the coal industry fell sharply; that the metals and machinery sector had the lowest level of disputes in total days and in days per 1,000 employees since the measure was first introduced; that disputes were low in New South Wales, Western Australia and the Northern Territory; and that 53 per cent of all disputes were of less than 24 hours duration, meaning that they were a typical 24-hour stoppage or some period less than that.

Senator Childs asked me whether this shows a continuing advantage for the consensual approach to industrial relations that the Hawke Labor Government promotes through the accord. One of the elements in these lower figures, which I have acknowledged publicly, must be the fact that the economy is flatter, and that works against industrial disputation. In saying that, I point out that this Government has had an unparalleled record in reducing the number of days lost independent of the state of economic activity. For example, economic growth averaged over 4 per cent in the financial years 1987-88, 1988-89 and 1989-90. In these years industrial disputation was, on average, over 60 per cent lower than working days lost in the last full financial year of the Fraser Government, 1981-82-a year in which the economic growth was 1.6 per cent.

In other words, in a high growth scenario there was still a dramatic fall in the level of disputes under the accord and during the period of this Government. That leads to the comparison that there has been a drop of 62 per cent in the level of industrial disputation comparing the life of the Hawke Government with the period immediately following that of the Fraser Government. If we want to put that in a reverse way, we could say that Liberal industrial relations policies impose a $2 billion handicap on the Australian economy.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of reports that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) in conjunction with the Australian Chamber of Manufactures and the Australian Mutual Provident (AMP) Society has launched a new investment fund called the Development Australia Fund? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the existence of that fund and I congratulate the parties involved, particularly the ACTU, which has been pursuing the idea for some time. The AMP Society, the ACTU and the Australian Chamber of Manufactures announced this fund at a launch today. It is to be called the Development Australia Fund.
