ANSWER.PARA: The fund has been designed to provide union and employer superannuation funds with the opportunity to participate directly in the development of Australian industry. That is an opportunity I fully support. While the fund will include traditional listed equity and fixed interest components, it will also include a sizeable low cost housing finance component and a significant development capital component. This development capital component will be managed by the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) with the aim of making `patient' capital available to Australian firms. I should say that the AIDC is, I think, the largest manager of development equity funds for Australian industrial companies and has done that, I think, with considerable success. The fund will develop companies and projects which encourage employment creation, the expansion of exports and import substitution, the development of new technologies and technology transfer, and increased Australian ownership and participation.

As the honourable senator will be aware, I have for some time been expressing concern at the apparent lack of capital available to fast growing Australian businesses. It is a matter of public record that earlier this year the Treasurer and I had some discussions with the major superannuation funds on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the one that Brian Howe didn't bother to turn up to.

—No, Brian Howe was not asked. That is a typical smart interjection-wrong again. These discussions occurred because it appeared that these major financial institutions play a much smaller role in development capital markets in Australia than their counterparts in countries such as the United States of America and the United Kingdom.

ANSWER.PARA: I should state that at no stage has there been any attempt by the Government to prescribe or direct how superannuation and life offices should invest their funds, or whether a set proportion of funds should be set aside for development capital purposes. The discussions were about the perceived constraints on the larger funds investing in these areas, and whether these constraints have arisen in Australia for any particular reason. I accept without qualification that the investment practices of superannuation funds must be dictated by their own commercial considerations and judgments.

Against this background the fund which has now been established, and the AMP Society's central role, is a very welcome initiative. The AIDC's role in this fund will be one of its strengths. As I said, it has a proven performance as a provider of development capital, and this new source of funds will provide it with the opportunity to enhance its operations in the future. It is to be hoped that the Development Australia Fund will become something of a model for other superannuation fund managers and trustees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's comments recently about the state of development of cooperative research centres, can he comment about how this development fund may be working with the new cooperative research centres?

—I cannot comment on that in detail, but I do know that there has been considerable interaction between the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, for example, which will be a substantial beneficiary of the cooperative research centres program, and, I believe, the AMP Society, and certainly some other funds. Those interconnections are very important and can only be encouraged and cultivated.
—Mr President, I ask that the Minister table the document from which he is reading.
—I table the document.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Now that the Government has managed to engineer the recession that we had to have, how many more Australian children will need to live in poverty as a result?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston and, I think, other honourable senators, have asked me questions on this matter a number of times. I have said in all of those answers-and I note that the Prime Minister did so in a written answer to Mr Webster in the other place recently-that there is no accepted poverty line, so I am not prepared to put a figure on how many Australian children are living in poverty or how many are likely to. All I can say is that, if one Australian child is living in poverty, it is bad, and we ought to be doing all we can to make sure that it is not the case.

ANSWER.PARA: In any recession there will be families in trouble. That has to happen. If we are in a recession and people go out of work then, clearly, their economic circumstances will be worse and that will put pressure on Australian families. What the Government will do is ensure that the benchmarks which we announced on child poverty are met. They were met in July 1989. We shall continue to ensure that they are met. I hope that during the next two years we can begin to lift those levels up a bit and do all that governments can do to make sure that no children live in poverty. However, irrespective of whatever government income security payments there might be, I do not think a government could ever guarantee that no child would have that kind of problem.

As for Mr Hawke and the 1987 promise to which Senator Kemp referred last night, I have said in the past last year that all we needed was to add the word `need' to `live in poverty' and we would not have had any sort of problem. The Prime Minister has acknowledged that error himself many times since.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I am grateful to the Minister for saying that he now does not believe that there is any recognised level of poverty. Can he please explain, therefore, on what basis the Prime Minister could have made the original statement or, indeed, a statement about any need to live in poverty? On what possible basis can one talk about benchmarks having been met if one does not know what the level of poverty is in the first place?

—The benchmarks refer to percentages of the combined rate of pension, not to a poverty line. As far as the Prime Minister is concerned, I have already explained that he has acknowledged the error that was made in 1987 several times, and so have I. We can go on acknowledging it if it makes Senator Alston feel better, but it will not change anything.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to the comments made by Professor Desmond Ball on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's PM program on 27 November that the facilities at Nurrungar and Pine Gap will have a significant role in the provision of operational intelligence to United States (US) forces in the Gulf both now and in the event of war. I also refer him to the answers given to question 51 of the honourable member for Hindmarsh in the House concerning the provision of Pine Gap data to Israel as part of a deal involving the sale of United States patriot missiles to that country, and particularly to the answer to question 52 from the same honourable member concerning the impact of our even-handed policy on the provision of such data. I ask: can the Minister assure the Senate that all data we supply from Pine Gap and Nurrungar is approved by Australia before going to the Americans in the Gulf? If not, why not? Further, can the Minister assure us that data is not going to Israel either directly or via the Americans and, if not, why not?

—The Government has said on a number of occasions that the joint facilities serve Australian and US interests through the provision of intelligence and other information essential to our defence requirements. In November 1988 the Prime Minister made a major announcement in the House of Representatives outlining the roles and functions of Pine Gap and Nurrungar and their fundamental contribution to Australian, US and international security. I have nothing else to add. In answer to Senator Vallentine's supplementary question, I have nothing further to add.

—I thank honourable senators opposite for the opportunity to ask my question a little earlier than normal, and I direct it to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the position of the States regarding exempting the $2.50 a week pharmaceuticals supplement for pensioners and beneficiaries from assessment when setting public housing rent levels? Can the Minister also report on the progress of discussions with the States on the issue of the Commonwealth providing a direct debiting facility for State housing rents?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As all honourable senators would be aware, from 1 November all pensioners and beneficiaries who were previously entitled to free pharmaceuticals received either $2.50 a week or a $50 a week advance to compensate them for the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme announced in the August Budget. After March all of those in the higher income levels who receive a part pension will also receive that $2.50.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Community Services and Health, Mr Howe, wrote to State and Territory housing Ministers on 23 September to ensure that this $2.50 for pharmaceuticals was not assessed as income when the State housing commissions were determining levels of rent. Unfortunately, only the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory have so far formally agreed to this request, although the indications are that the other States will go along with that request at least until March. What happens after March is a matter of some concern.

To ensure that that $2.50 fully compensates all of those affected for pharmaceutical charges, the Government has decided that that amount will remain as a supplement, that it will be tax free and that it will not be taken into account in setting nursing homes and hostel patient contributions or in assessing child-care fee relief. Obviously, it is absolutely essential that that $2.50 be kept fully available for pensioners and beneficiaries to use when they are purchasing prescription items.

Even though the States have indicated that they will quarantine that amount only until March, we live in hope that we will get some positive response as to what will happen after that. Pensioners and beneficiaries are entitled to certainty before that date as to what will happen. The Minister, Mr Howe, is attending a meeting today, as I understand it, of State housing Ministers so that he might very forcefully put the view, not on behalf of the Commonwealth Government but on behalf of pensioners and beneficiaries, that the States keep their hands off that $2.50.

It is worth noting that at the moment the States are campaigning very strongly to have the Department of Social Security agree to the direct debiting of rents from social security payments. If the Commonwealth was prepared to look at that it would be doing so on a totally voluntary basis. It would be up to the client to determine whether he or she wanted that deduction to occur. As a minimum response the Commonwealth would expect the States to quarantine the $2.50 permanently. Were the States not to do so, they could hardly expect the Commonwealth to cooperate in the direct debiting of rents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to an article in the Melbourne Age of 28 November in which the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Bob Hogg, is quoted as saying that the Minister is preparing legislation which would prohibit third parties, such as farmers, teachers, pharmacists, pensioner groups, and so on, from advertising during election campaigns, which would prohibit paid election campaign advertising on television and radio, and which would compensate television and radio stations for free time by a rebate of licence fees. I ask the Minister: firstly, will it become standard practice for the Government's legislative program to be announced by Labor Party officials? Secondly, following Mr Hogg's pronouncement, can the Minister confirm what legislation is being prepared and when it will be introduced? Thirdly, what has changed since the Minister's predecessor, Mr West, described such legislation as unworkable, saying that it would not achieve the objectives sought? Finally, does the Minister not realise that this would represent one of the gravest attacks on freedom of speech and expression in our history?

—There is probably a lesson for Senator Parer in this matter; that is, he should understand that the Labor Government is not necessarily doing what Bob Hogg says. No legislation is being prepared at the moment. The Government is still considering the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Once we have finished considering that, we will announce what we will be doing. The rest of the questions are based on a hypothetical premise and I will not answer them.
—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister: is he preparing legislation or is he not? If so--
—He has answered that.
—He has not answered it; he said that it was under consideration, I think.

—It took Senator Parer six days to find the article. He has not realised that, in answering the initial question, I have already answered the supplementary question. He would have saved the time of the Senate had he listened the first time round.
—Order! I acknowledge the presence in the public gallery of the Hon. Mark Birrell, the Leader of the Opposition in the Victorian upper House, and I welcome him to the Senate.
—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: are professional artists able to claim as tax deductions the value of works they have painted and donated to a charity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have an answer to this question. It is not a matter on which I am expert, but Senator Cooney has pursued me about it before. He has a great interest in the topic. The answer is that a professional artist is able to claim as a tax deduction, under the so-called taxation incentives for the arts scheme, the value of a painting which is donated for inclusion in a collection maintained by the Australiana Fund, a public art gallery, library, museum or art bank. Under the scheme certain gifts of works of art and other comparable property qualify for deduction on a more liberal basis than other gifts.

ANSWER.PARA: Broadly speaking, the scheme allows a deduction for a qualifying gift to be based on its market value rather than on its costs. The scheme also does away with the requirement that the property given must have been bought by the taxpayer within the previous 12 months. The deduction for qualifying donations is generally based on the market value of the property at the time it was donated, which is determined by reference to the average of two or more valuations obtained from approved valuers. However, in certain circumstances the deduction will be based on the cost of acquiring or producing the property. This will be in a case where an artist or an art dealer donates in the ordinary course of business a painting which is not from his own private collection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware that Mr Brian Burke, then the Premier of Western Australia, was fully briefed on the severe problems of Rothwells Ltd's receivables and solvency at a meeting in the Premier's office in December 1987 with Rothwells' directors, David Hurly, Tony Lloyd and Bill Burgess? Is the Minister also aware that the Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke, stated in evidence to the McCusker inquiry into Rothwells that he was unaware of the review of its receivables undertaken by Mr David Hurly and in so doing grossly misled that inquiry, the Parliament and the people of Western Australia? Has the Minister inquired into the Ambassador's propriety in this matter? If not, will he do so?

—My answer to Senator Campbell is exactly the same as that which I offered in this place on 27 November, namely, I am not aware of the specific matters to which he refers. I do not propose to initiate any exercise of the kind that he invites me to. My answer in this matter is the same as it always has been: if and when some evidence emerges through the courts or elsewhere, or something that would make it inappropriate for the ambassadorial position to be maintained, I will act, but not sooner.

—In view of that answer I will ask a supplementary question, probably exactly the same as my supplementary question on that same day. Since these matters are not allegations, they are matters of clear public record and they do imply some impropriety on behalf of the Ambassador, will the Minister inquire into the matter I have now raised?

—I do not accept Senator Campbell's characterisation of those matters. My answer remains the same. I have nothing further to add, nor will I be likely to have anything further to add on this subject until such time as circumstances may arise of the kind I have described in my answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of the reported statements by the Tasmanian Premier, Mr Field, that the conservation war in Tasmania is over? Is the Minister also aware of the endorsement by the Tasmanian Premier of legislation identifying areas of permanent timber production-a concept which in some circles is referred to as resource guarantee legislation? Does the Minister agree that such legislation is akin to a land grant for exploiters? What measures will this Government take to ensure that such plans will not eventuate and therefore compromise the equity which all Australians hold in our natural resources and to ensure that they will not compromise the right of all Australians to derive benefit from the community's assets?

—I think it desirable that conservationists and industry are aware of what areas will be exploited and what areas will be preserved for conservation purposes. If the effect of the legislation of the Premier of Tasmania is to guarantee adequate areas of protection and adequate areas for resource development, then he would be fulfilling for all Australians a valuable role because the forests of Tasmania have a reputation, a deserved one, around Australia as being very special. I cannot claim, Senator Bell, to be aware of the specifics of the legislation to which you refer. I shall ask Mrs Kelly to give me a brief on that and if there is anything I need to add to the answer I shall certainly do so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I congratulate the Minister on the intention behind his Offshore, What For? campaign launched recently which aims to encourage Australian tendering for Federal Government contracts, and is directed at both suppliers and purchasers. However, in light of the fact that Australia's boat building industry was not even asked to tender or quote for a multi-million dollar cruiser purchased by a Qantas Airways Ltd subsidiary; and in light of the fact that this 3,500 tonne boat is being built in a Fijian Government shipyard, before returning to Australia to take away business from established private operators, I ask the Minister: does this not contradict the objectives of Buy Australian, Advance Australia, and Offshore, What For? campaigns? Is he not embarrassed by the investment of taxpayers' money in a ship built offshore without even giving Australian industry a chance to bid for the contract?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator O'Chee has a couple of basic misconceptions about the Offshore, What For? campaign and also has a misconception about government purchasing and the structures within which that purchasing is conducted. What he has to acknowledge and what has of course been driving politics on his side of Parliament for some time is that we have recognised that we do not have artificial barriers to purchasing within Australia. The aims of efficiency and building a competitive industry in Australia are best enhanced if we do not have those sorts of artificial trade barriers.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the first point I make. We have moved away from the policy of compulsory acquisition of goods made in Australia. Secondly, the campaign of Offshore, What For? and the Buy Australian campaign have been in operation now for a couple of months. They have been conducted not only on a Federal level, but also in recent weeks we have obtained support from all State governments and Territory governments across Australia for it because those governments recognise the advantages to the Australian economy of educating government purchasers, particularly in an era where purchasing policy dictates that departments go off and buy their own. There is a certain degree of devolution of purchasing power and authority, an autonomy within individual departments.
What governments have recognised and what I am sure local governments will also recognise are the advantages of educating purchasing officers towards buying Australian products.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question asked very specifically in relation to a vessel and a tender process, and the Minister has now been waffling for at least three minutes on very general propositions. If he does not know the answer, could he please say so that we can get on with Question Time.
—Order! The Minister was asked two questions. One was about the campaign and one was about a specific ship. He is talking about the campaign, and he had not been going for three minutes.

—I am sure that Senator Alston, if he were a bit patient and did not show the normal arrogance he shows in Question Time, would actually learn something from the answer. Governments across this country recognise the advantages of educating purchasing officers. One of the basic reasons they recognise that is that governments across Australia have a purchasing bill of $30 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: That purchasing bill, if it is exercised in a way that emphasises the quality of Australian products and emphasises the need for Australian producers to produce products of quality, will mean not only enhanced purchasing from within Australia but also that Australian producers will enhance the level of quality of their products and will be able to compete internationally as a consequence thereof. Had Senator Alston been listening, he would have heard that within what I have said so far I have mentioned that there has been a devolution of purchasing power and purchasing autonomy and responsibility.

The second part of Senator O'Chee's question refers to the tendering process of a subsidiary of Qantas for a particular vessel. I will redirect that particular question to the Minister responsible for Qantas and its subsidiaries who will come back to us. Having said that, I stress the fact that the Purchase Australian campaign has just got off the ground. It is one that is also being appreciated by Australian industry. Opposition senators can sit over there, marginalising themselves, playing in the nets while we are on the main pitch, but the reality is that the campaign will continue. It has support, and it has support from the business community. It is a pity those on the other side do not show a bit of support as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his comments on competitive pricing. I am just a little bit confused. I do not understand how Senator Bolkus can talk about competitive pricing if the Australian industry is not even given a chance to tender. Perhaps he would like to address his mind to that particular problem.

—At the risk of boring the Senate through repetition-I have already explained to Senator O'Chee that I will pursue this particular item-let me say once again, in response to Senator O'Chee, and drawing on the experience I have had from questions I have received in recent days from Opposition senators, that just because Senator O'Chee makes a claim, it does not mean it is true. I will refer the question to the relevant Minister and come back with a specific answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the Minister inform the Senate what will be the benefits for Australian primary industries, and in particular for the wool industry, of the Government's recent credit agreement with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The signing on 23 November of a memorandum of understanding between the USSR and Australia, aimed at expanding mutually beneficial trade and economic co-operation between the two countries, and the subsequent signing of a credit agreement totalling $400m between Austrade EFIC and the Soviet Foreign Economic Bank, Vnesheconombank, for the purchase of wool and other Australian commodities by trade organisations in the Soviet Union represents a watershed in our relationship with the USSR and is good news for our embattled wool industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian offer to provide credit to facilitate trade was made in response to a request from the Soviet Prime Minister, Mr Ryzhkov, to Mr Hawke and was designed to permit the resumption of normal levels of trade. It is expected that the wool industry will be the largest beneficiary as traditionally it accounts for three-quarters of the trade concerned. However, the Australian offer is predicated on the Soviet side paying by the end of this year all the moneys owing for wool and other products shipped earlier in the year. The Soviet authorities have confirmed their intention of meeting this condition.

Soviet officials have indicated their eagerness for a quick return to the wool market, as Soviet wool mills are in urgent need of Australian wool supplies. The benefits of the credit arrangement will not be confined to wool. The Soviet side showed strong interest in purchasing Australian butter. A Soviet delegation recently arrived in Australia to discuss the purchase of up to 100,000 tonnes of Australian mutton. In addition to wool, meat and butter, discussions also covered a major Australia-Soviet joint venture for the production of alumina and the supply of Australian bauxite, alumina and manganese. Negotiations in these areas were not so promising, but may result in the development of trade in these commodities at a later date.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I draw the Minister's attention to an out of court settlement of $5m that was agreed to by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Finance and officers from the Australian Construction Services to a builder for a blow-out of costs associated with work on the Concord Repatriation Hospital. In that his Department's management practices failed in the costing of the project, failed in cash flow management and further failed in not providing appropriate architectural advice or ensuring adequate supervision during construction and thus contributed substantially to the blow-out, can the Minister explain how these management failures could have occurred, and what action he has taken in relation to them and to prevent any recurrence?
—Mr President--
—Resign!

—No, Senator Richardson, I do not think I will resign. What I will do though is give advice to Opposition senators on matters such as this. If they want full answers in the spirit of cooperation, then questions such as this should go on the Notice Paper, otherwise they can give me some notice of them. Given that this is a department of 16,000 people with a massive budget and given my responsibility to the Senate, I shall come back here with a full answer to Senator Newman's question. Questions requiring detail and based on presumptions such as that should be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it from that that the Minister regards a loss, a blow-out in costs, of $5m in taxpayers' money as a matter of such trifling concern that he takes no responsibility for such an important matter in his own Department? Clearly he knows nothing about it, but are we to assume that he regards it as trifling?

—Senator Newman would be wrong to make any assumption, especially one based on the sort of mentality that drives her mind. What I said was that a question such as that should be placed on the Notice Paper.

—My question which is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce relates to the subject of information technology. I ask: what are the implications for Australian industry development of the Government's adoption of open systems in the information technology field?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, recently announced the Government Open Systems Interconnection Profile, and procurement of information technology systems by Government agencies will be expected to conform to GOSIP. This will be mandatory from 1 August 1991 and Government departments will be required to develop strategic plans that outline how they will move to open systems. The Information Exchange Steering Committee is the body charged with furthering the development of GOSIP. This is only a first step towards adoption of the wider concept of open systems and is consistent with the direction being taken in information technology in developed countries throughout the world.

ANSWER.PARA: These markets are currently dominated by the proprietary systems of a few major computer vendors. Consequently it is often difficult for their customers to transfer data and generally communicate between different systems; to attach peripheral equipment from alternative suppliers; to expand by upgrading from one system to another, sometimes even while staying with the one supplier; and to run applications easily on more than one brand of equipment.

As open system standards become fully defined and more widely available, they promise to overcome these difficulties. Users, including Australian industry, should benefit from the more competitive markets that result, particularly industries like software suppliers. Smaller suppliers, such as the many Australian companies with expertise in both software and services, will have access to wider international markets using open systems. Presently these firms target particularly proprietary systems and it can be difficult for firms to grow in that environment. The benefits of these larger, more open and competitive markets will only come if there is assurance that products adhere to the agreed standards. Accordingly, it is important to have locally developed software tested for conformance to open systems. I am encouraged by some proposals which have been put to the Government for conformance testing in Australia and these have recently been brought to the close attention of Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. I refer to the fact that the Department of Community Services and Health on 1 December introduced major changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, whereby generic equivalents were to be substituted for brand name drugs. I ask: is the Minister aware that pharmacists have not yet received the December edition of the pharmaceutical benefits price book which details the prices to be charged for generic equivalent drugs? I might mention that they already have the kit that has been sent out to advertise it. Is it true that two entire sets of books were printed in advance for the December edition, each with a different price differential based on two alternative prices which had then not been determined by the Tribunal? Is the Minister aware that a number of generic equivalents for drugs such as Maxolon, Serepax and Indocid are not obtainable at present?

—I have some information on this, although not formally in the brief. The fact is that there was a difficulty in getting out the pharmaceutical benefits scheme booklet to pharmacies. I understand that a booklet or proposed listing of the various prices was printed in anticipation that the Pharmaceutical Benefits Tribunal would make its determination in accordance with the Act in a way which would enable the period of notice or the information to be given to pharmacists, and doctors for that matter, as speedily as possible. For one reason or another that did not occur, but I understand that the postage from the printer was completed on the night of 30 November and that it has gone out. I understand from advice received today that all pharmacists in Australia can expect to receive the booklet or listing by today. Many of them will have received it by yesterday. I understand that that important set of information is now in the hands of pharmacists. The new list of prices and so on was made available to the Pharmacy Guild midway through last week. It covers about 90 per cent of retail pharmacists, so it was available to them to distribute through their system. I do not know whether it did or not. I understand Senator Herron's concern about this matter. The printing has been completed and the distribution has taken place, so I am advised.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I checked with pharmacists in Townsville and Brisbane today at 1.30 p.m and was told that they had not received the booklet. Was the Minister asked by the Pharmacy Guild to defer the introduction of the scheme until 1 January in order to overcome the problems previously outlined?
—I do not know whether the Minister was requested in those terms but I will ask and provide an answer to Senator Herron.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is it a fact that a shipment of 85,000 sheep was recently rejected by Saudi Arabia because of the presence of the disease scabby mouth? Could the Minister advise whether there are any Commonwealth or other guidelines concerning the quality requirements for export of live sheep and, in particular, whether those guidelines include vaccination?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —A shipment of Australian live sheep left Australia in October for Saudi Arabia and on 22 November, upon arrival at Jeddah, was refused entry. The ship contained 85,000 Australian sheep. There were at that time unconfirmed reports of infection, which was contagious, of pustular dermatitis, otherwise known colloquially as scabby mouth. I understand that there was an Australian veterinary surgeon travelling with the ship. Subsequently, I understand that Dick Austen, the Chairman of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) is reported as saying that some scabby mouth infection was included within the flock on board the vessel.

ANSWER.PARA: To answer the second question, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation directs exporters under the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act on pre-voyage checks for health and for quality controls before sheep are dispatched from Australia. The directions that they operate under are directions that have been worked out previously with industry, which has a vested interest in maintaining quality in order to consolidate and enhance the Gulf trade on live sheep.

It is also a fact that a vaccine has been considered by the industry and the AMLC to determine what can be done to guarantee disease free sheep on arrival. Those considerations have resulted in industry and the AMLC rejecting the proposal. However, in view of the rejection of this shipment of 85,000 sheep, a number of options are now being considered, including the vaccination option.

Given the public comment of the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, that growers would be out of their mind or mad if they did not embrace the vaccine, it should be said that there are a number of problems with the vaccine. Firstly, the vaccine is live; it causes scabs and can transmit diseases itself. Secondly, it is not commonly used on farms because of the possibility of transmitting viruses during storage. Thirdly, it takes 40 days before the scabs stop appearing after the administration of the vaccine. I am advised that if one contains the vaccine on a vessel during voyage it could result in a disease outbreak itself. I am also advised that it requires long preparation times before a departure. All those things are matters to be considered on our side.

We also have to consider the importing country's view of the vaccine and the attitude it will have to the implications of its use. However, the matter is under consideration with a number of other options and obviously a decision will be made in due course. This is a vital trade to Australia and the Government is committed to sorting out the problems with that trade as speedily as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 November Senator Panizza asked me a question about a locust outbreak in Western Australia. I have now been supplied by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin, with an answer to that question. As it is a long answer, I ask that it be incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: I am unaware of any request from the Western Australian Government for assistance from the Commonwealth Government in the current plague of the Australian plague locust.

However Wilson Tuckey M.P., member for O'Connor, made a written request to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy for a pro rata contribution from the Commonwealth equal to one quarter of the annual amount it would contribute to the Australian Plague Locust Commission (APLC). This funding was to assist in the control campaign against the Australian plague locust in Western Australia.

A reply was sent by the Minister in early October indicating that the APLC was funded on the basis that its Charter directs it to control locusts which pose a threat to agriculture in another member State. Should a locust outbreak occur in one of the member States which does not constitute an interstate threat, control of the outbreak becomes the responsibility of that State and not the APLC or Commonwealth. The locusts in Western Australia do not pose a threat to agriculture interstate.
The APLC receives 50% of its funding from the Commonwealth and 50% in varying proportions from Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland and South Australia.

The Agricultural Protection Board of Western Australia (APB) requested that two of their staff, who would be key officers in the coming campaign, receive some training from the APLC prior to the campaign commencing. The members of the APB were included on a training course run by the APLC on locust survey and control techniques in early August at Longreach, Queensland.

The APB have also made several requests for chemical from the APLC. The loans were made on the proviso that an order for replacement chemical be placed immediately as the locust season in eastern Australia was likely to be busy with the possibility of aerial spraying operations.

Initially 46 tonnes of technical fenitrothion were sent in mid August 1990 to enable the APB to organise their own chemical distribution prior to the outbreak. A further loan of 36 tonnes was made in late October-a total of 82 tonnes representing 80% of the Commission's chemical stocks.

A request for a further 50 tonnes of technical fenitrothion was received from the APB in late October. At the time the Commission was engaged in its own spray operations against a moderate scale outbreak in central southern Queensland. As it was still early in the locust season the Commission felt it unwise to deplete its chemical stocks further. The Commission currently has 24 tonnes on hand and aerial spraying operations are likely to recommence in Queensland in the near future.
The New South Wales Department of Agriculture and Fisheries was able to loan the APB 35 tonnes of technical fenitrothion.

The most serious plague of the Australian plague locust in the eastern States, since the Commission's inception in 1974, took place in the Riverina of New South Wales in spring 1984. One hundred tonnes of technical fenitrothion was sprayed by the Commission during this time. Judging from the amount of chemical being requested by Western Australia the plague must be very serious indeed. Dr Gordon Hooper, the Director of the Australian Plague Locust Commission. spent a week in Western Australia observing and advising during mid November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

This report includes a number of statistics which indicate a serious situation within our society. It details the latest cumulative figure relating to divorces and the latest cumulative figure relating to children affected by divorces. In my view, extra efforts need to be taken to promote marriage stability in light of the cost of divorce to community and individuals. Added to the financial costs must be the even greater cost in terms of the breakdown in human relationships and the effect that this has on children and society as a whole.

Without denying individual responsibility, it must be said that the Federal Government has contributed to the pressures against marriage and the family. It has done so in a number of ways, including making it impossible for many families to live on one income; failing to recognise the financial value to society of the full time home-maker; turning Family Court counsellors into counsellors for divorce; giving de facto relationships the status of equal value to marriage in certain circumstances; promoting a promiscuous society by its support of a hard core pornography industry; and insufficient funding for marriage reconciliation counselling services and for marriage education for the young.

Some years ago I sought to amend the Family Law Act to require marriage partners intent on separation to undergo counselling for the purposes of considering the legal, social and financial consequences of divorce and, in particular, the effect that divorce would have on children. Under my amendment, an application for divorce could not be filed unless such reconciliation counselling had been undertaken at least 12 months beforehand. While some Government members considered that the proposal had merit, the Government voted against my measure. Had my measure been adopted, thousands of marriages could have been saved.

It is no good the Government bewailing the cost of divorce if it fails to give legislative support for the institution of marriage. The latest figures that are supplied in the Family Law Council report that is now before us, show that in the 13 years since the Murphy Family Law Act, which allowed for easier divorce, became operative in 1976 there have been 599,496 divorces and 705,279 children have been directly affected. I believe that that should be noted. I believe that we should always have that in the forefront of our minds when considering the issue of family law in Australia.

The summary in this annual report tells us a great deal about this Government's parsimony in providing funds for the appropriate and proper description of the incredibly rich and diverse flora and fauna of this country. Indeed, only several weeks ago I was speaking to a world expert-who shall remain nameless-on one whole family of organisms. He expressed the view that, at the rate at which we were going, we would not complete the biological survey of Australia until the year 3000. In other words, more than a thousand years from now we will still be describing the incredibly rich and diverse and in many cases unique plant and animal forms which share this land with us.

In the meantime we are destroying species in this country almost as fast as we can go. We have one of the worst records in the world as regards the extinction of vertebrate animals. The list of both animals and plants which lie on the verge of extinction, which are threatened and which are regarded as endangered species is long indeed. Against that background we have a very small sum of money set aside to describe properly what is in this country before it disappears forever.

To take one example, it has come to my notice in recent weeks that the numbat is an animal which was prevalent right across southern Australia at the time of white settlement. It was last described in New South Wales in the 1860s, and it is now confined to about 200 animals in one small pocket of Western Australia. The number of numbats has seriously declined in the past 10 years. Not enough is known about the breeding habits and the ecology of that species to guarantee its survival. It may well be that into the next century there will be no numbats anywhere in Australia, anywhere in the world or anywhere in the universe. RESPONSE BY SIR WILLIAM KEYS, A.C., O.B.E., M.C.
AGREED TO BY SIR WILLIAM KEYS
THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES
PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5 (7) (b) OF THE SENATE OF
25 FEBRUARY 1988

In the Senate on Thursday, 15 November, I was the target of most insulting remarks from Senators Newman and Herron. I write to ask that my response to these attacks and to the issues from which they arose might be presented to the Senate.

Senator Newman referred to me as a Government ` `stooge'' because of my support for hospital integration. In this role I developed sound working relations with Prime Ministers from Robert Menzies to Robert Hawke. I believe I also had the respect and confidence of my own constituency and the Ministers and Governments of the day, regardless of their political persuasion.
The results achieved for veterans and dependants over that period are a matter of record and speak for themselves.

I briefly retrace this history of my efforts for veterans and dependants to make the point that Senator Newman's interjection was not only deeply offensive, it was untrue. I am nobody's ` `stooge'' and never have been. The views I express are at all times my own.

It is not the personal attack on me which concerns me: rather, it is the attack on the concept of integration. As National President of the RSL I negotiated the integration arrangements with Prime Minister Hawke and Veterans' Affairs Minister Humphreys. The views expressed in my letter, quoted by Senator Tate, represented views adopted by organisations such as the Korea and South East Asia Forces Association and the TPI Association.
Subsequently, in supporting Senator Newman's attack, Senator Herron was incorrect in his statement to the Senate in relation to a National Conference of the AMA on 26 May at which I spoke.
He said I had returned from overseas that morning. In fact, I had returned 5 days before.

He said I had delivered a speech that I had not actually read. In fact, the speech I read was the third draft of an address on which I had worked with the National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition (NOOSR) in which I provided the general thrust and the professional people provided the supporting data-a fairly normal procedure for such a speech.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 November, on the motion by Senator Michael Baume:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, this matter is inexorably drawing to a conclusion while, of course, the benefits of the report will continue to flow on. It continues to unravel. There is one particular matter I want to address in the very short time I have available to me that relates to a particular incident. The concern I have is that it reflects, frankly, on the competence, the capacity and the integrity of some of our sporting officials which has led to the problems we have now.

SPEECH.PARA: The interim report disclosed that the assistant manager of the Australian track and field team for the Edinburgh Games, Mr Maurice Plant, had sought to cheat by trying to get, and he succeeded, from a young Australian athlete who was subject to his direct supervision, a clean urine sample and to substitute that for the urine sample which was supposed to be given by an athlete who had just competed in an event. Mr Plant assumed that that athlete had cheated by taking anabolic steroids and therefore would test positive and thus be disqualified.

The committee, of course, had some concern about that matter and thought it sufficiently serious to inquire as to what steps had been taken by Athletics Australia Inc. to inquire into the matter-I would have thought not an unreasonable concern or request. As a result of that, Athletics Australia was written to on 9 March 1989, at least on the first occasion, and it responded on 22 August, some five months later. The response was from a Jeanette Brown, acting general manager, and she advised the committee that Athletics Australia's inquiries had been particularly limited-she did not say so, but that was the upshot of her correspondence-because Miss Jane Flemming, the young athlete from whom the sample had been solicited, declined to comment on the matter other than to say that she had produced a sample. The letter stated:

As a consequence of the problems that arose with Miss Flemming not prepared to make a written statement, a mail vote to Associations conducted at that time amended the law regarding investigations to read:

``If the person or club or association concerned fails to respond to the request for a Statutory Declaration within the specified time, the person, club or association shall be suspended forthwith until such time as the response is received.''

In other words, it sought to ensure that Athletics Australia had a proper mechanism in place to allow it to inquire properly as to matters of this nature. That motion and that rule were introduced because Miss Flemming was not only unhelpful but, in fact, she covered for Maurice Plant and she actively obstructed the inquiry. However, no inquiry appeared, to my knowledge, to have been made in respect of Mr Plant. Accordingly, Athletics Australia was written to and asked a number of questions relating to Mr Plant. On 6 August, it wrote back to the Committee and observed:
The I.A.A.F.-
that is the International Amateur Athletics Federation-

which is Athletics Australia's governing body, and the British Amateur Athletic Board have both investigated these specific matters and have resolved to continue their professional relationship with Mr Plant.
It went on to state:

Athletics Australia believes it would be counter-productive to impose any continuing penalty on Mr Plant in these circumstances. As stated in our letter of March 12th, 1990, Mr Plant will not be appointed to any managerial positions with Australian Athletic Teams and it is therefore our firm request that the matter should rest.

Following that correspondence we were told that the International Amateur Athletic Federation had inquired into the matter. I wrote to that Federation and asked what correspondence, facts, circumstances and events it took into consideration in making the inquiry in the determination which was referred to us by Athletics Australia. The response from the International Amateur Athletic Federation was in these terms:
IAAF has not specifically discussed the incident in Belfast. It would not be appropriate for us to do so, as the meeting concerned was not one conducted directly by IAAF.

The Federation went on to say that it understood that the matter had been satisfactorily dealt with by Athletics Australia, which was a clear contradiction. The correspondence we received from Athletics Australia was, frankly, thoroughly untrue. The Committee was misled. There was no inquiry by the International Amateur Athletic Federation and, if I had not bothered to write to the United Kingdom seeking that information, to this moment that knowledge would not be available to us.

There is one other point I will touch on in the very few moments that remain to me in this debate. I inquired what Mr Plant's duties were and his relationship with young Australian athletes on the International Amateur Athletic Federation grand prix circuit. I was advised by Athletics Australia that the IAAF council decides from time to time in its discretion both to establish commissions and to determine the membership thereof. Athletics Australia is not involved whatsoever; consultation is not sought.

The reason that I raised those questions is that I thought it was very inappropriate that a man who had conducted himself in the way Mr Plant had should still hold that position. But I was assured by Athletics Australia that he was in that position and that the appointment was made without-to quote Athletics Australia- `even their consultation'. They had no input into that appointment. I wrote in respect of that matter to the International Amateur Athletic Federation, which wrote back to me in these terms:
Mr Plant was nominated by the IAAF-
and then one sees in brackets-
. . . (and with the approval of Athletics Australia) as a member of our IAAF Grand Prix Commission.

In one letter from the IAAF it repudiated what had been said and found two lies that had been told to me and to the Committee by Mr Prince, a member of the Australian Sports Commission, and by Mr King, the Executive Officer for Athletics Australia. It is for these fundamental reasons that we now find ourselves setting up a publicly funded Australian Drugs Sports Agency because we cannot trust the integrity or the honesty of officials of this calibre at this level to conduct themselves in a proper and appropriate way. They cannot be allowed to be involved in testing because we cannot be satisfied, and clearly nor can the Government, that we will receive the facts and that the tests will be conducted in an uncorrupted way. It seems to me a great indictment that people of this calibre are on these bodies.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the report of the Committee entitled Jindalee over-the-horizon Radar. I seek leave to move a motion in respect of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report
I seek leave to incorporate my remarks in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The report which I have just tabled deals with construction of a network of over-the-horizon radars, together with associated facilities. This network will consist of radars in the Longreach area of Queensland and the Leonora region of Western Australia, a coordination centre at RAAF Base Edinburgh in South Australia, and a number of very small, remote beacons and sounders. The cost of the public works aspects of the proposal is $95 million.

The Jindalee radar works on the transmitted signal from an object being reflected off the ionosphere before illuminating a target area on the earth's surface. Use of the ionosphere enables the radar to `see' over the horizon for distances up to 2000 kilometres from Australia's northern coastline.

Referral to the Committee was based on an agreed ceiling price of $125 million for the public works aspects of the project. During the Committee's considerations, the cost estimate was revised to $95 million. Based on revised tenders, this was made up of $40 million for each of the radar facilities, $10 million for the coordination centre and $5 million for the remote beacons and sounders. We have asked for details of the split of expenditure on the antennas and other facilities when a contract is awarded.

The Committee accepted that there was a need to establish the Jindalee network to carry out effective surveillance of ship and aircraft movements up to 2000 kilometres from Australia's northern coastline. To provide optimum performance, radars need to be located in the Leonora area of Western Australia and in the Longreach area of Queensland.

The Department of Defence proposed that, instead of using the more traditional `design and construct' method, it would use the `turnkey' approach. In this approach, all works will be provided by the prime equipment contractor as an integral part of building the radar and all the services which go with the prime contract.

The Committee has recommended that Defence provide it with an analysis of the effectiveness of the turnkey approach at the end of the project, concentrating on its cost, co-ordination and timing aspects compared with traditional project delivery systems.

The Committee has a continuing interest in the efficient use of energy and was very concerned about the forecast consumption of fuel at the radars together with problems associated with connection to the Queensland state power grid. Accordingly, we have recommended that a high priority be given to overcoming these problems; that the use of alternative energy sources, especially solar energy, be fully investigated for their application to the project; and that discussions be held with adjoining landowners being consulted about connection to the state grid.

While the Department of Defence believed it had carried out an adequate program of consultation with the Longreach community, we have recommended a further program be undertaken, based on that which was part of the public environment Report process in Western Australia.

In the Longreach area, there were community concerns about the project, and some submissions opposed it. There were also submissions in favour of the project and a considerable number of individual expressions of support. We took an amount of evidence in Longreach, from both groups, and believe that after Defence personnel had given evidence on a range of issues these local concerns had largely been resolved.

These concerns centred on the effects of electromagnetic radiation as people, stock and buildings would be within a 25 kilometre radius of a site proposed for the transmitter. A considerable amount of evidence was taken, and supplementary material provided, on this subject and Committee accepts advice that the appropriate Australian Standard and design standards are being applied.
Nevertheless, it believes an urgent independent assessment should be made of the electromagnetic effect of a Jindalee transmitter at the site proposed near Longreach.

This was a particularly interesting inquiry which saw the Committee inspect likely sites in the Leonora and Longreach areas, hold public hearings in Kalgoorlie and Longreach, and visit the existing Jindalee Facility at Alice Springs. On behalf of the Committee, I would like to thank all the people who helped us during that long and eventful week.
I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was privileged to be a member of the Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) delegation, together with the Speaker, Leo McLeay, the Hon. Clyde Holding, Mrs Kathy Sullivan, and Mr Max Burr. I hope that, despite the heavy load on honourable senators, they will take the time to read this coverage of the eighty-fourth conference of the IPU, as it includes a number of very important and most topical resolutions and recommendations. With due deference to time constraints, I would like to run through some of the major issues as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I wish to highlight two supplementary and emergency items. The first detailed support of all parliaments for the United Nations resolutions condemning the annexation of Kuwait by Iraq and the search for means likely to re-establish peace in the Arab-Persian Gulf. The second emergency item related to support for United Nations Security Council resolution 672, concerning the violence against Palestinian civilians in the holy places of Islam on 8 November 1990 and the need to adopt appropriate measures to protect the Palestinian people. The full text of these resolutions is provided on pages 93 and 99 and both resolutions were passed with acclamation.

The conference agenda focused on two major issues: firstly, eliminating colonialism and its consequences in strengthening cooperation between developed and developing countries, and exploring different models of regional cooperation; and, secondly, an issue in which I was especially interested and monitored all areas of the debate was literacy and education as essential factors in the liberation of women and men to promote their participation in the democratic life and necessary instruments for development.

These two major items for debate involved six plenary sessions and 157 speakers. Madam Acting Deputy President, as you can appreciate, the sessions were lively with extensive debate resulting in numbers of resolutions going into the Inter-Parliamentary Union committees for further study and, hopefully, action. The conference devoted three sittings to the general debate on the political, social and economic situation in the world in which the leader of the Australian delegation, the Hon. Leo McLeay, spoke of Australia's commitment to promoting freer trade. As members of the Australian delegation, we were all delighted that Mr McLeay was also successful in being elected to the IPU executive committee. I am sure that all senators will congratulate him not only in his capacity as representing both Australia and the Asia-Pacific region.

One of the most important outcomes of this eighty-fourth IPU conference was the increased participation of women parliamentarians, which now stands at 16 per cent of all participants at the latest IPU conference, that is, 59 women from 39 countries. Women parliamentarians met for one day prior to the conference, and a number of us met on the final day to assess progress and future action. Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure you will be interested to know that it is only a few short years ago that the response from the IPU to requests for women to have a special session was to invite them all to an afternoon tea. Clearly, a great deal of progress has taken place since that somewhat paternalistic response. The women parliamentarians were not only vocal at their own day conference but also were very visible in all areas of the conference during the week. Participants at the special women's meeting proposed this item for inclusion in the agenda of the eighty-fifth conference:
Policies to put an end to violence against children and women in private life, in social customs and in situations of marginalisation.

We were very pleased that that was adopted by the full and final session of the IPU. Other recommendations of special relevance to women and children are detailed on pages 35 to 39. I am sure all senators will welcome initiatives to focus greater attention on women within the IPU and, therefore, women around the world.

Mrs Kathy Sullivan was a member of the drafting committee on the item of the elimination of colonialism. I am sure that, as the first permanent woman member of an Australian IPU delegation, Mrs Sullivan will continue to actively monitor a range of issues, especially as it was her item that was approved by the women's conference to amend the statutes of the IPU to include gender as a criterion for selection to all important and influential drafting committees. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that all countries are now requested by the IPU executive to include at least one woman in their delegations. Regrettably, not all countries are complying, but Australia has had a very good record, certainly this time with one permanent delegate and me as the second woman of a five-person delegation.

Time prevents my detailing other important outcomes of the eighty-fourth IPU conference. However, I would like to draw special attention to the resolution relating to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child which in summary: welcomed the declaration and plan of action of the World Summit for Children; urged national groups to press governments to early ratification and implementation of the convention and to ensure adequate financial resources; and called on national parliaments to monitor the implementation of the World Summit for Children plan of action and the convention. I trust that all senators will support the Government when formal ratification proceeds.

I would just like to take this opportunity to say it is regrettable that there has been such a campaign of misinformation against the convention. Perhaps in the spirit of the season we can all focus attention on the need for governments in Australia and, indeed, around the world to focus more specifically on the needs of children and to ensure that more adequate resources are directed towards children.

Finally, it would be remiss of me not to congratulate Mr John Dyer and the officers who were responsible for the very speedy completion of this report. I understand that on some occasions reports from IPU conferences can be much later in their finalisation and tabling. I would like to congratulate them on this most comprehensive report, and the fact that we are able to table it today and see just how relevant so many of its resolutions are. I commend it to all honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter related to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. The Bill enforces the Government's stated policy of encouraging unions to amalgamate and makes relevant the provisions in this legislation to make that process easier. It is the teeth behind this entire proposal. In considering this Bill, it is very important that we place the attitudes of the Opposition into context on this matter so that we can fully understand and appreciate why it does oppose a number of clauses, and reject its position accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: It was suggested at the second reading stage by some Opposition senators that this Bill and the Government's push for amalgamations was simply a result of the Government trying to appease the Australian Council of Trade Unions and various undefined union interests. It was further argued that because of this only evil left wing union bureaucrats would benefit. Conspiracy theories are not new or even very novel things, but that particular one would have to be one of the silliest that I have ever heard. The facts are there for all who choose not to ignore them.

Five independent studies have identified the reduction in the number of unions as an important step in achieving a more cohesive and successful industrial relations system. This Bill in particular will achieve that aim in place of irrational debate on the merits or otherwise of this course of action.

At the second reading stage the Opposition merely pointed to a document produced by Bill Kelty three years ago which argued for reforms along similar lines to those being proposed by the Government. Before we know it, we have a conspiracy on behalf of left wing trade unionists! This initial suspicion of the Bill seems to have tainted it completely in the eyes of Opposition members because they seem completely unable to deal with it on a rational level. Their opposition to this clause is indicative of this phenomenon.

At the second reading stage their criticisms of the amalgamation provisions fell into one of either two categories: either the proposal is no good because it will not achieve its stated aim of reducing the number of unions in each individual workplace or, more importantly, in the eyes of Opposition members it is bad because entrenching large unions would make it even more difficult for the Opposition's much heralded policy of enterprise bargaining to be implemented if and when the unfortunate happens and members of the Opposition stumble into government.

Occasionally when speaking on this matter, Opposition members stray from these criticisms on to less relevant but no doubt more satisfying areas of out and out union bashing. It might be worth looking at these remarks, if time permits, for if anything could be said to be the intellectual underpinning of the Opposition's position and its direct rejection of this clause, this is it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighty-two per cent of workers in this country are covered by private sector awards. Unfortunately, some 47 per cent are not receiving, according to the latest statistics, the superannuation entitlements accorded them as benefits under private sector awards. Clearly, something is seriously wrong when almost half the workers in the private work force who are entitled to superannuation are not receiving it. The proposed amendments in this Bill to the Industrial Relations Act go a substantial way, I hope, to addressing the problems.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of background, until five or six years ago the vast majority of private sector workers received no superannuation at all. The lucky few who did tended to be in industries that had very substantial bargaining power in terms of their union representation; they tended to be concentrated in higher paid jobs; and they overwhelmingly tended to be male.

Through the accord process, this Government initiated the introduction of superannuation for all private sector workers in this country. In my view, it is one of the most significant reforms to be carried out. Not only do workers have 3 per cent superannuation but also the intention is to ensure that this should increase to 6 per cent over the next four years. That in itself will not provide totally for persons in their retirement but it is a major achievement of this Government that we have come so far in such a short time.

Why is it that such a significant number of workers are not receiving their legal entitlements under private sector awards? From my experience as a trustee of an industry fund known as Host Plus, which covers the hospitality industry and which currently has membership of 70,000-this is expected to grow to 250,000 in the next year-there is a mixture of both ignorance and deliberate evasion.

From my experience in the hospitality industry, there is certainly considerable ignorance by employers about their obligations in respect of industry superannuation. I suppose that is not unexpected given the nature of superannuation and the requirements that are necessary under the various awards. However-and I regret to say it-in many instances there is deliberate evasion by employers.

It annoys me particularly that although employers I deal with would quite ruthlessly deal with workers who steal money-that is, they would dismiss them and quite rightly so because stealing cannot be condoned-a significant number of those employers are stealing from their workers by not providing their superannuation benefits.

By way of example, it has been drawn to my attention that in some instances in the hospitality industry employers simply do not provide workers with the appropriate documentation for superannuation, which they are required to complete. In fact, they deliberately discourage their work force from completing that documentation and, hence, they avoid paying superannuation. This is clearly evidenced by the fact that in many workplaces in the hospitality industry there is a 100 per cent compliance in terms of the work force and yet in other workplaces there are many instances of 100 per cent of the work force not receiving superannuation.

As I understand it, this is because many employers deliberately discourage employees from belonging to funds in order to avoid their 3 per cent obligation. Clearly, if that is allowed to continue, it can only become worse in the sense that workers over the next four years will become entitled to 6 per cent under the accord. The retirement policy of this Government and this nation will be severely weakened if employers do not meet their award obligations.

I am glad to see the amendments before the Senate today which provide effective mechanisms to ensure that employers meet their obligations. They provide effective mechanisms in the following way: firstly, it certainly seems to me absurd that if an employer is caught not paying the award obligation in the case of superannuation, interest is not payable on the outstanding amount. I would like to demonstrate the cost to the employee of the failure of an employer to pay interest. With your consent, Madam Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate a table in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we perhaps have a look at it? Senator Sherry could continue his speech and then we will give an answer.

—The table I wish to incorporate contains an actuarial set of figures prepared by an insurance company. It is based on wages ranging from $10,000, $20,000 to $30,000 a year; a calculation is made in terms of a 3 per cent contribution; interest of either 12 per cent or 15.5 per cent is added-it obviously will vary; and then a final figure, including interest, is given of the amount a person would be entitled to after 25 years.

SPEECH.PARA: If one excludes the interest figure-in other words, if an employer is able to avoid paying interest on the moneys, the 3 per cent that he or she is obliged to pay-the effective amount of money that a worker receives is 83 per cent less than that worker should have received. In other words, referring to the first line of the table, a worker receiving $10,000 a year and receiving a 3 per cent superannuation contribution, which earns an average of 12 per cent interest over a 25-year period, should receive $44,800. However, if that worker does not receive his or her interest-and this is one of the important aspects of this amendment; it ensures that where an employer has not paid his or her superannuation contributions interest will also be required to be paid-all the worker receives is $7,500, not $44,800. This illustrates the appalling situation that has been occurring where employers have been caught not paying their superannuation contributions. Even if employers do pay it after having failed to pay it for some period, in many cases years, they are then obliged to pay that sum of money, including the interest that the employee has missed out on.

That is the major part of this piece of legislation about which I am concerned and I am very pleased to see that it is being introduced into the Industrial Relations Act. In addition to that, there is also a mechanism by which employers are required to keep records for six years. Of course, there is no practical effect in having those sorts of provisions and enforcement clauses in awards if employers are not required to keep their wage records, because it becomes very difficult to work out what employers owe their workers-whether it is superannuation or any other wage entitlement-if there are no wage records. It also becomes very difficult to prove that in a court should it become necessary.

In concluding, I commend these amendments to the Senate. They are very important and they clearly mean that some hundreds of thousands of workers in this country who are not receiving their legal entitlements to superannuation will find it a lot easier to secure them through the courts if it becomes necessary. I also commend the campaign being conducted by the Arbitration Inspectorate at the present time to ensure that superannuation payments are being met by employers. I believe that the policy of this Government in terms of retirement packages and in terms of ensuring that workers receive superannuation has been one of the greatest advances for people in this country. It is an excellent example of what the Labor Government has accomplished under the accord, in very stark contrast to the miserable attempts by those opposite to ensure adequate retirement benefits for workers in this country.
