TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 12, page 5, insert the following clause:
``12a. After section 187 of the Principal Act the following Division is inserted in Part VIII:
DIVISION 4-DIRECTIONS
Directions to stop industrial action

`187a. (1) Where it appears to the Commission that industrial action is occurring, or is threatened, impending or probable, in connection with an industrial dispute, the Commission may give, in connection with the exercise of conciliation powers or arbitration powers in relation to the industrial dispute, such directions as it thinks necessary or desirable to prevent or stop the industrial action or to prevent further industrial action.
`(2) A direction under subsection (l) may be given to:
(a) a party to the industrial dispute;
(b) a member, officer or employee of an organisation that is a party to the industrial dispute or;
(c) any other person engaged in industrial action in connection with the industrial dispute.
`(3) The Commission may give a direction to a person not to engage in conduct that hinders, prevents or discourages:
(a) the observance of an award;
(b) the performance of work in accordance with an award; or
(c) the acceptance of, or offering for, work in accordance with an award.
Injunction to stop industrial action

`187b. (1) Where, on the application of the Minister, or of a person who is a party to the industrial dispute or is bound by the award concerned, the Court is satisfied that a person has engaged, or is proposing to engage, in conduct that constitutes, or would constitute:
(a) a breach of a direction under section 187a;
(b) an attempt to breach such a direction;
(c) aiding, counselling or procuring a person to breach such a direction;
(d) inducing or attempting to induce a person to breach such a direction;
(e) being in any way, directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in, or party to, a breach of such a direction; or
(f) conspiring with others to breach such a direction;
the court may grant an injunction in such terms as the Court considers to be appropriate.
`(2) Where in the opinion of the Court it is desirable to do so, the Court may grant an interim injunction pending determination of an application under subsection (1) or (2).
`(3) The Court may revoke or vary an injunction granted under subsection (1) or (2).
Damages for conduct in breach of direction

`187c. (1) A person who suffers loss or damage by the conduct of another person that was done in breach of a direction under section 187a may recover the amount of the loss or damage by action against that other person in the Court.
`(2) An action under subsection (l) may be commenced at any time within 3 years after the date on which the cause of action accrued.
Other actions not affected
`187d. Nothing in this Division limits a right to bring an action otherwise than under this Act.
Conduct by officers, employees, members or agents

`187e. For the purposes of sections 187b and 187c, action taken in breach of a direction under section 187a by an officer, employee, member or agent of an organisation shall be deemed to have been taken by the organisation, unless the organisation establishes that it took all reasonable steps to prevent the person from taking the action.'.''.

This is the Opposition's only amendment to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. It is an important amendment and a rather lengthy one. It has been circulated and I presume it is available to senators in the chamber. The Opposition proposes to add a new clause 12a to this Bill to insert a new procedure, which would thereby make new sanctions available to improve, in our view, the enforcement provisions under the Industrial Relations Act. The code that we are suggesting is fully set out in the amendment, which has been moved in another place and I am sure is well known to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who is at the table, and to those honourable senators who are interested in it.

The features of the amendment include the provision that, where the Industrial Relations Commission is aware that some industrial action is taking place or is being threatened, it may, through the exercise of its conciliation or arbitration powers, give such directions to the various people concerned in that industrial action as would prevent it from occurring further. The amendment sets out to whom these directions may be given. In general terms, they would be given to those who are taking part in an industrial dispute, who may be members of an organisation, or to the organisation of which they may be members and so forth. The directions would be in the wide form of a direction to observe an award or to perform work in accordance with an award and so on.

That direction having been given by the Commission, it could then be enforced in the courts, such as the Federal Court of Australia. That jurisdiction could be invoked by either a Minister or a person who is a party to the dispute or who is bound by the award. If the court is satisfied that there has been a breach of a direction or relevant conduct which is similar to a breach, such as aiding a breach or something or that sort, it can do two things. It may grant an injunction to stop that sort of behaviour occurring, and we are familiar with on what grounds court injunctions can be issued. It can also award damages for any loss or damage suffered by a person if that person can establish to the court's satisfaction that that loss was suffered as a result of a breach of the direction.

That is the framework of the Opposition's amendment. It is a proposal of some standing in the industrial relations debate. It is not something new; it has a history over the last three years. The proposal was embodied in a Bill that Senator Chaney, the then Opposition's shadow Minister for industrial relations, introduced in the chamber in, I think, 1987. Although it failed then it was reintroduced as an amendment to the Government's Industrial Relations Bill which was passed by this chamber at the end of 1988. A similar amendment was moved at the committee stage of our consideration of that Bill by Senator Chapman on behalf of the Opposition. That amendment also failed. The Opposition is now taking the further opportunity of an Industrial Relations Act amendment to press forward its proposal once again. The Opposition is doing so because it attaches great significance to this proposal and it represents a very important feature of the Opposition's industrial relations policy.

In short, the Opposition's argument in support of this proposal is that when legislation imposes obligations on employers, as the Industrial Relations Act certainly does-it imposes obligations on employers to abide by awards-it should also impose enforceable obligations on employees who benefit from an award. The Bill which has been introduced by the Government, to which we are moving an amendment, proposes to improve the rights of employees who have benefits under an award. Those improved rights relate substantially to occupational superannuation, which is a new feature of awards. Difficulty has arisen in enforcing the obligation of employers in relation to their contribution to occupational superannuation funds as required under awards.

As that has been covered in the second reading debate, I do not propose to expand on it. But the reality is that the Government is strengthening the enforcement rights of the beneficiaries of the awards. We think this is another opportunity to emphasise the fact that this ought to be a mutual process and that there ought to be a similar provision in the Industrial Relations Act to give employers who are affected by industrial action by employees or by organisations of employees to require observance of the recognised standards of industrial behaviour.

This is not a proposal which has been suddenly dreamt up in the last few years by the Opposition. It is a proposal that has been in the industrial relations debate for many years. It was the reason behind the introduction of bans clauses, or the power to insert bans clauses in awards, a number of years ago. Unfortunately, nobody seems to believe that the bans clauses have been very successful. A former Minister for Industrial Relations in this Government, Mr Willis, had the carriage of the major rewrite of the industrial relations legislation in October 1988. He first introduced legislation in 1987 to give effect to the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems and referred to the need for an industrial relations system which would provide equal protection to both sides of a dispute-namely, employers, or employees or their respective organisations. I do not need to go through the history of what happened to those proposals except to say that ultimately they were abandoned. The new Industrial Relations Act 1988 did not make any further improvements than the old legislation had provided. We believe, as obviously Mr Willis believed, that the Act would be improved if there were such a balancing between the rights of both sides to industrial disputes.

I would have thought this would be an attractive approach for a Labor government which is so committed to maintaining the existing industrial relations system with all the paraphernalia of the Commission, the award-making process and so forth, because it provides for a system of enforcement and sanctions to which employers or their organisations, or the Minister or the Government, can have recourse to ensure that the conduct of employees or their organisations does not offend the general standards that are expected in a system of conciliation and arbitration.

When trying to conciliate or arbitrate, members of the Commission make a judgment-it is not made by a court-as to whether a certain conduct should cease. I would have thought that feature would also have been attractive to the present Government. The proposal does not take away common law rights or other legal rights under, say, section 45d of the Trade Practices Act, but it gives employers or their organisations an alternative right to seek sanctions within the existing system and thereby be very much under the control of the high priests of that system in the Industrial Relations Commission. It does not assign the same powers of outsiders as actions in common law or actions under the Trade Practices Act.

Although, as I have said, the Opposition is not proposing any change in that availability to that recourse as a matter of law, and would resist suggestions that that should be the case, nevertheless, we are proposing an alternative system that would be very attractive, in our view, to employers and more acceptable to employees as indeed it was clearly acceptable as an alternative to a former Minister for Industrial Relations and the Government of which he is a Minister.

The Opposition puts forward the proposal as one which would improve the existing system. Despite our deep concerns about many aspects of that system and our other proposals to make major changes to it, we assume that for some time to come there will be a need for the present system to operate in much the same way as it is and has been doing. This is a way of providing a fair way for both sides to have recourse to enforcement provisions. Apart from the final decisions of a court, the circumstances which will give rise to those legal rights will remain very much within the control of the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has just been said, this is an amendment proposed in the committee stage to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990. It is an amendment that deals with the penal clauses, sanctions or compliance provisions of the Act, whichever heading takes one's fancy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine and Senator McLean have said that the Government will review the provisions of the Act next year. I should say on behalf of the Government that that is true. I announced in April of this year that we would review those sections of the Act relating to union amalgamations as a priority. We will go on in our review and deal with other matters where there is broad consent between the parties, and pick them up in any amendments where we can. We will review at greater leisure, in 1991, the more substantial questions where there is conflict and disagreement.

Of the two Bills that are to be dealt with this afternoon, this one, the No. 2 Bill, is a Bill in which there is substantial agreement between the parties about superannuation provisions and so on. As a consequence, it will go through, as it did in the House of Representatives, relatively untouched and uncommented on. The other Bill is the end of the process, as far as the Government is concerned, on the union amalgamations approach.

What I intend is to open up the process of a general review of all provisions of the Act at the National Labour Consultative Council being held next week. In that process I expect, and everyone would imagine, that there will be attention to the compliance provisions or the sanctions. As a consequence I imagine, too, that when I bring forward amendments to the Act in the Budget session next year, there may be in that Bill some dealings with these matters. It is true that in 1991 there will be a long process of consultation to which all parties can contribute. Probably, at the end of that, there will be some legislative change in which the Senate can participate in debate. I make that explanation to underline the points made by Senators McLean and Harradine about the approach of the Government.

What we have here is the ritual amendment moved by the Opposition whenever industrial relations matters come before this chamber. It does so to make its own points. It has made them again this afternoon. I do not want to deal in great detail with all of those points, except to say that it comes down to a fundamental difference in approach between the Government and the Opposition on industrial relations. Where there is a dispute the penchant of the Opposition is to look for revenge through penalty and pain, and inflict it in whatever way it wants on one or other of the parties.

In the Government's view where there is a dispute we seek resolution. We seek enduring peace by changing whatever are the relationships that are necessary to bring it about. We seek to build a cooperative spirit between the parties, engender harmony in the workplace, remove divisions which give rise to disputes and hopefully, generate greater productivity that can then be shared in terms of profit and wages. That is a fundamental difference which may illustrate itself again when we next debate industrial relations. A lot of the concerns of the Opposition spring from its obsession with penalties.

Before I resume my seat, I would like to deal fairly quickly, as I think I am bound to, with some of the aspects of the amendment that need to be mentioned. The amendment introduces a compliance system heavily and inequitably weighted against the trade union movement and in favour of employers-so much for the argument of balance! Some of the inequitable features of the amendment are that there would be no appeal against the making of directions; there is no defence to an alleged breach of a direction; a person may sue for damages incurred as a result of a breach of a direction, even though no injunction has been issued by a court. They are some of the inequitable features. They just prove that this lopsided approach to compliance seems better calculated to provoke what is called the destructive adversarial behaviour in industrial relations rather than eliminate it.

In addition to those features of inequity in the amendment that I have identified, it suffers from other deficiencies which are likely to hinder rather than promote good industrial relations. Let me just briefly mention a couple. It derogates from the role of the Industrial Relations Commission by providing a fast track to the Federal Court of Australia. The grounds on which an injunction may be issued are vague. The Court need only be satisfied that a person has engaged or is proposing to engage in conduct that constitutes, or would constitute, a breach of a direction, an attempt to breach such a direction, aiding counselling or procuring a person to breach such a direction, or inducing or attempting to induce a person to breach such a direction, being in any way, directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in or party to a breach of such a direction or conspiring with others to breach such a direction. It has to be said that the availability of direct and immediate access to such a process could well be used to thwart and frustrate efforts by the Commission to resolve an industrial dispute.

Paradoxically the proposed scheme might delay the availability of remedies for industrial action. There is a clear risk that enforcement proceedings in the Court could undermine attempts by the Commission to resolve the underlying issues. Given the severity of the remedies and the lack of any sensible process for cooling off, it would be understandable if the Commission and employers treated directions as a process of last resort and were reluctant to use them for fear of inflaming a dispute.

I should add that it is hardly conducive to sensible industrial relations if an interim injunction can be obtained without any examination of the merits of a claim. An application could be made on the strength of a mere apprehension that a union is proposing to attempt to induce a person to breach a direction. It is self-defeating to introduce processes which will completely undermine the commitment of the trade union movement to the conciliation and arbitration process.

These proposals are also quite contrary to the objective of encouraging commitment to sensible grievance procedures. The Opposition has simply forgotten the lessons it had to learn, not at its cost but at great cost to the community in the 1960s, when the coalition Government introduced processes for dispute resolution and access to the enforcement of bans clauses was permitted. It expressly acknowledged that there were two main deficiencies in the existing processes which gave virtually immediate access to penalties. These were the immediacy and availability of enforcement measures. The processes did not allow the Court to take hold of a dispute between the parties and endeavour to assist them to resolve it. These fundamental weaknesses are reinstated by the Opposition's proposals.

Far from being a prescription for improved industrial behaviour, these proposals represent a return to the discredited confrontationist approach to industrial relations of the Fraser Government. They will make disputes worse and, as has been said by one judge in relation to the common law action in industrial disputes, leave `a legacy of bitterness between the parties'. I oppose the amendment. I note that the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine have indicated similar opposition. I therefore expect the amendment to fail.

SPEECH.PARA: In a number of contexts we have emphasised that we have serious reservations about the alternate model, from which Senator Durack argued at the second reading stage and presumably will argue in this committee stage. We have serious reservations about the deregulated labour market because we think it will create big winners and big losers. Therefore, we have simply addressed this Bill, from the beginning over a period of about four months, positively and hopefully constructively. Our 13 amendments hopefully will be judged to reflect that attitude.

We have had a lot of consultation, initially with the Opposition, starting four months ago. That petered off for the reason which I have mentioned-that it was simply unproductive. We have had a lot of consultation with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), with members of his staff and with departmental officers. I would like to express a very sincere appreciation for the extraordinary cooperation that we have had in that process of consultation in an attempt to improve the legislation. The amendments that we will be moving in the next hour or so reflect that long process of consultation. I think it was probably hundreds of hours of consultation with community groups, with the Government and, as I said, initially with the Opposition but less so in recent times.

From our consultation with community groups and from our first reading of the legislation, it was apparent to us that we had about nine areas of concern. These areas mainly centred around the rights of individuals. I will be returning to that and flagging the concept of an industrial ombudsman which focuses precisely on some continued reservations we have in that area, and I understand that the Minister will speak to that concept later.

Over the four-month period we have had seven or eight papers from departmental officers and other sources explaining and elaborating various aspects of the legislation. So, slowly but surely, we have narrowed our areas of concern down to relatively few. I believe that this legislation is very well intentioned and that it has been very well drafted. However, it has been our intention to attempt to improve it.

We have not adopted the same attitude as the Opposition, whose bottom line attitude, as I said earlier, has been to simply oppose it in to, irrespective of anything. I know that the Opposition will consider some of those amendments for reasons which it has given. However, it believes that some of these amendments will weaken the Bill and, therefore, it will support them. The Democrats believe these are amendments which will strengthen and improve the Bill. We believe that there was a lot of unnecessary fear about the implications of clause 10. Clause 10 requires that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission consider whether or not it should consult with peak councils in relation to certain matters. I emphasise that this clause simply requires that the Commission consider whether it will consult with the peak councils. The fear arose through a misinterpretation that it was placing a requirement upon the Commission to consult with peak councils; in other words, a requirement to consult with the Australian Council of Trade Unions or a requirement to consult with the Confederation of Australian Industry. SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats' amendments have been made, with the consent of the Committee, to both the proposed new sections 118 and 118A. I do not think that the amendments were necessary. Proposed section 118A widens considerably the role of the Commission compared to existing section 118. The powers that are repeated in 118A are widened, however, beyond the demarcation disputes. The Opposition's concern about that is bound up with its concern about the whole purpose of this Bill to hasten the process of amalgamations to herd as many employees into as few unions as possible. It almost seems to be giving the smaller organisations a second serve because it is giving the Commission the power to make orders about whether they will represent those employees in particular industrial disputes. It is something for which the Opposition has an in principle objection for the same reasons as we have to the whole purpose of this Bill, which is not only to hasten the amalgamation of unions, but also to reduce to 20 the number of unions from a present level of over 300. However, the Opposition's objections to proposed section 118 are based upon the same concern that the Government is quite determined to reduce the role and significance of smaller unions in the industrial relations system at the expense of creating much larger unions than the workers choose to be members of, and to operate within.

The Commission could here order that an organisation of employees is not to have the right to represent under this Act the industrial interests of a particular class or group of employees who are eligible for membership of the organisation. The existing organisations which seem particularly concerned about this are the professional organisations and one can see why because their coverage in relation to a particular class or group of employees may well be removed, not simply to resolve a demarcation dispute, but also, as far as coverage is concerned under the pressure of larger organisations, to force them into an amalgamation.

As I said, our objections to this clause are bound up with our objections to the whole purpose of this Bill. Nevertheless, as this clause has been singled out for attention in this debate, the Opposition wishes to register strong objection to it. However, the Opposition maintains its objection generally to this legislation and we will record that objection further by voting against the third reading of the Bill as we voted against the second reading. I do not propose to divide the Committee on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not support this amendment, the intention of which is to delete this whole clause. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with the amendment to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, I would like to bring some figures to the attention of those of us who are involved in the debate. Before I do that, I will refer to a few things that have happened here tonight and some of the comments that have been made. I would suggest to Senator McLean that there is only one person in this debate who is a square sitting in a round hole, and that is himself. The only way he will get into a square position is by hopping over to the other side. All he has done to this point is vacillate; he has not really contributed anything whatsoever to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of reducing the figure from 20,000 to 10,000, let us look at a few facts and see how many people and organisations this will scare. Currently, there are some 140 registered Federal employee organisations in Australia. One hundred and two of them have fewer than 20,000 members and 90 have fewer than 10,000 members. So all the honourable senator is talking about is 10 registered employee organisations. I do not believe that what the honourable senator is saying has any substance in terms of creating fear about those organisations.

Let us take it a little further in the context of this amendment. Whether we are looking at the 20,000 figure or the 10,000 figure, the stated objective is to improve industrial relations in the workplace. I am sure that all honourable senators have seen the survey that was conducted by the Business Council of Australia. That survey indicates that by making these changes we will create a situation where there will be an average of just over four unions in each workplace as compared with the current figure of five. I suggest that this will not have the impact that it has been suggested it will have.

Let us take the whole scenario a little further and consider whether efficiency in the industrial relations system will make us better off. I believe we will find that a whole group of organisations which were previously registered organisations under the Federal system, will move to become deregistered organisations. That has already been suggested to me. I have already indicated that I have great reservations about the current centralised wage fixing system. If people think that will improve the situation, I would suggest that they are very wrong.

We are told that amalgamations will overcome problems in the industrial relations system. Let us look at a pet subject of mine-the damage that is being done now in the meat industry. The first point I want to make relates to measuring industrial disputation in this day and age and the way that the tactics have changed in relation to that. It is not the size of the union or the number of days lost that is really the crucial point; it is the dollars and cents that an action costs the community. Often one sees a very small action in relative terms of the number of people who are out of work. But the flow-on effect through integrated industry and integrated systems results in the loss of millions and millions of dollars.

Let us look at one union-the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU)-in terms of this amalgamation process. I am disappointed that there is little balance in the presentation of this process. That organisation has 45,000 members around Australia. The amalgamation process will make no difference to their attitude to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. I see that Senator Cook is looking across and probably checking the figures. The figures I received today indicate that the total membership of the AMIEU is 45,000. As far as the meat industry is concerned, the process will have no impact whatsoever on the activities that have been occurring. It will have no impact on the massive losses which are amounting to close to $100m. There have been some 20,000 days lost in working time-which, incidentally, is very close to 25 per cent of the total time lost in the last 12 months.

I do not believe that this so-called magical figure-whether it be 20,000 or 10,000-will contribute to a better industrial relations system in this country. I do not believe that it will assist in overcoming some of the problems that we have at the present time in some of our major industries. Over the last two or three years there have been problems in two main areas-the meat industry and the coal industry. Millions of dollars have been lost in these very important resource-based industries.

I cannot support the setting of a number of members, whether it be 10,000 or 20,000, because I do not believe it will achieve the objectives. I believe that this legislation will create a situation where we will see more and more organisations moving away from being registered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I was interrupted earlier this evening I was saying that almost all coalition honourable senators who spoke in the second reading debate claimed that reducing the number of unions from the present 299 to an ideal number of 20 would have no effect on the number of unions representing workers in individual workplaces. I think the chances of that happening would be fairly small. I would have thought that the likely result would have been a significant reduction in the number of unions per workplace. That would seem to me to be logical.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's major complaint, however, is that this process of amalgamation would forever prevent the possibility of a system of enterprise bargaining gaining a foothold in our industrial relations system. I am not sure if this is a particularly relevant criticism of the Bill directly, but it is an interesting example of the lack of real understanding that honourable senators opposite have of the industrial relations system in this country, and their complete inability to see past their own outdated prejudices in constructing a relevant, realistic and achievable industrial relations policy.

Let us look first at this system they champion so loudly-this system of enterprise bargaining. What the Opposition wants is for workers to negotiate terms and conditions directly with their employer, perhaps through the agency of a company-type union, limited in its scope to that enterprise alone. This type of structure, based very much on models drawn from Japan, would allow negotiations between employers and employees to be based on the individual firm's ability to pay wages and other conditions without being forced into centralised arrangements which can have dire effect on the productivity of individual firms. It does not sound too bad in theory. The Opposition supports its theories with case studies of firms which have adopted such arrangements to find that the successful firm ends up paying lots of money to its happy workers. As I said, that does not sound too bad. But the practice of enterprise bargaining does have its own down sides. If the firm is having a rough time, there are no prizes for guessing whose wages get the chop. And if the union is confined to the enterprise, one wonders how much industrial muscle it will have to prevent this occurring.

The Japanese system, as it classically operated, had a slight variation to it which overcame some of these problems. What they used to do was have different classes of workers. The permanent workers were the elite: they belonged to the union; they belonged to the company; they were part of the family. They were given company homes, health plans, even superannuation in some cases. They were very well looked after. Seasonal workers, taken on for given periods, were another story all together. They did not belong to the union. They worked longer, harder hours. They had no protection. They were not looked after if they fell ill or even if they were killed. If the company was unprofitable, they were laid off.

That is the happy tale of enterprise unionism which honourable senators opposite are apparently intending to inflict upon an unsuspecting public. It creates a permanent underclass of one shape or another. Either one union is stronger than another, or one enterprise is more generous than another, or one worker is in a weaker position than another. It has that potential to create a permanent underclass which we as a humane society should not and can not tolerate.

I would recommend that before honourable senators opposite make impassioned speeches about the need for increased efficiency through enterprise bargaining, they sit down and read a book called Japan in the Passing Lane which details the dark side of the Japanese economic miracle. All is not as it appears on charts of economic growth and efficiency, and no responsible government, nor even a responsible opposition, should discount human factors in formulating policies on industrial relations.

Centralised waged fixation protects workers in positions of relative weakness, as well as providing for predictable and responsible wage outcomes. Enterprise bargaining provides no such guarantees. It is not as if enterprise bargaining, as envisaged by the Opposition, is even a realistic or achievable aim within the confines of our industrial relations system. The policies which those opposite proclaim so loudly as their glorious vision of a deregulated future were soundly rejected by the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems for the very simple reason that they were in practice unachievable.

Employer groups conceded as much in their submissions to the Hancock Committee. It was left to the gung ho reactionaries of the lunatic right and self-styled right wing think tanks-I use that term advisedly-to argue for the position that the coalition now endorses. The Opposition still has not come to terms with what Professor Hancock termed the `industrial realities': the existence of long-established industrial structures and practices which will not readily adapt themselves to fulfil the ideological dispositions of the Opposition. To believe that over 100 years of industrial relations practice can be altered to fit into the Opposition's views on what should or should not happen is almost childish.

How does it intend to control wage outcomes if a system of enterprise bargaining were implemented? If we moved away from centralised wage fixation, it is apparent to any reasonable observer that industrially strong unions would prosper. All that would be needed would be a flexing of their industrial muscle. Weaker unions would find it difficult to achieve such success, and their members would thus be exposed to any employer who wanted to take them on-a different underclass to the one I mentioned earlier with regard to Japan, but an underclass nonetheless.

There is no predicting what the wages outcome would be under such a system. Certainly a wages policy would be unachievable, and an accord-type arrangement unworkable. So not only would managing the economy become a practical impossibility but also wages would come to reflect the industrial power of the unions which represent the individual workers, and any concepts of equity would go out the window. This is the society those opposite so loudly clamour for. It has been suggested by the Opposition that this Bill would prevent the introduction of such a system in this country. All I can say is `Ah well, so be it'. We in the Government see that as a good thing and I believe that most Australians support us in that belief, and I sincerely hope they always will.

There are one or two arguments put up by the Opposition which I would like to deal with. The first is the argument that these mega-unions will be unresponsive to the needs of their members. It was, I believe, Senator Chapman who advanced these arguments most forcefully. There is no question that these unions will be bigger in a bureaucratic sense than their predecessors. It does not necessarily follow, however, that this will mean less effective representation of workers' interests. Certainly no evidence was brought forward to show that this would be the case.

Factors such as the number of members per union organiser, the ability of individual organisers, and the importance individual unions place on direct contact with their members are far more important in determining the value each member gets from his or her union. There are very good big unions and there are very good small unions. Some unions, both big and small, do not come up to scratch. If people are unhappy, there is always a reform team running in union elections these days that members can vote for.

One of the more unsavoury elements of the Opposition's attacks on this Bill was the pathetic allegation of union thuggery and corruption. It is a bit much when Senators Chapman and Walters make unsubstantiated allegations of-and I quote Senator Walters-`the intimidation, the strongarm tactics, the abuse and violence' as being commonplace at union meetings. When challenged by the Minister, Senator Chapman was unable to come up with a single example of such thuggery. That inability to come up with one concrete instance is, I believe, indicative of the reality of the situation, which is that such things are rare and notable exceptions. To refer to such things in the casual manner to which they were referred in the second reading debate is misleading, unhelpful and brings no credit on those who propagate these tired old stereotypes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the report on the waterfront?

—I know all about it because I have been involved in it all. The final point that I would like to make with regard to the criticisms of this Bill made by the Opposition on the second reading is this: Senator Durack made the comment that the process of amalgamations would of itself cause industrial unrest. He did not feel the need to prove the point in any way.

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence is that industrial disruption is not necessary or even likely to occur as a result of the amalgamation process. Some 10 major amalgamations in the last two years have not resulted in any industrial trauma that I am aware of. But there is an interesting, logical inconsistency with arguing for enterprise structures and a radical and overwhelming change to the structure of unions in this country and then, in the same speech, arguing against amalgamations of unions on the grounds of the industrial dislocation that this would cause. But I will leave it to those opposite to ponder those inconsistencies.

The Bill has one very simple aim: to make easier the process of amalgamation of unions in this country, thus facilitating an historic rationalisation of the number of union structures which operate within our industrial system. A key area of reform undertaken by this Government in all its terms has been reform of the system of industrial relations. Our achievements in that area have underpinned a successful wages policy which is now in its sixth form. But, whilst there has been a great deal of real reform in the area of industrial relations, one unhealthy aspect of the system still remains, and that is the archaic union structures which operate within the system. Many unions have been in their present form for over a hundred years, and it is obvious to all that structures which existed when Australia was a loose federation of States, with an economy based almost entirely on minerals and produce, require rethinking in a modern economy.

One of the major criticisms of our system of industrial relations is that it produces a complexity in any bargaining between employers and employees because of the multitude of unions involved in any one workplace. A survey commissioned by the Business Council of Australia showed that one or more unions were present in 95 per cent of all sites surveyed, with 50 per cent of workplaces having to deal with four or more unions. Within the public sector, there are some stark examples of the complexities which are faced by employers and unions.

In Telecom, there are presently 21 unions or staff associations; there are 22 such bodies representing employees in the tertiary-university sector; there are more than 50 unions within the Australian Public Service. The need for rationalisation is overwhelming. This is made even more so by the urgent need for this country to improve its international competitiveness. As has been said time and time again, this need has been recognised in independent inquiries since 1975. Now is the time to undertake this reform, and amalgamations are the logical and achievable way of doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason the Government has proposed that the minimum size of unions be 20,000 is to provide a positive incentive for unions in this country to comply with resolutions that they unanimously carry at peak meetings of the Australian Council of Trade Unions at the biennial congress of the ACTU to reduce the number of unions. The old demarcations are breaking down. The old craft system is going out. However, I recognise that the Opposition will not be supporting the 20,000 figure and in those circumstances there would not be a majority for the Government to stick with the 20,000 and reluctantly, therefore, I must accept the Democrat amendment, and so do, and support the 10,000 amendment.

In the debate on this matter a number of things have been said, some of which ought to be appropriately answered. Senator Crane cited the Business Council of Australia in terms of a finding it publicised. The first thing that should be said about the Business Council of Australia is that it is not, nor does it seek to be, a front-line industrial relations organisation. It does not field an advocate typically in landmark cases that appear before the Industrial Relations Commission and it is therefore not involved in the engine-room of industrial relations in this country. It preserves for itself the right to make observations across the landscape about industrial relations and many people do that, often with little interest, little backing or little experience in the field.

It should be remembered that the Business Council of Australia is a body in which the eligibility for membership is that a company must be one of the top 100 in this country. The top 100 companies' spokesmen say that small is beautiful: unions are not allowed to get big; unions should remain small. The largest 100 companies say that small is beautiful. If they believe that and are conscientious about it I expect that they will break up their organisations into small companies rather than remain as the large conglomerates they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was a survey.

—They express this opinion regularly. Senator Crane should know about it, and that is why I am telling him about it. Secondly, Senator Crane said that he could not see any advantage to the meat industry, which is his latest obsession, in terms of this legislation. I can accept that Senator Crane cannot see it. He has told us and I believe him; he must be right.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me propose for the rest of the Committee what some of the advantages for the meat industry may be. I am not saying that there will be advantages, but there could be. Where we are talking in this Bill about having an industry focus for union amalgamations-that is to say, unions are to be encouraged and facilitated to amalgamate along industry lines-in the case of the meat industry the possibility arises that it could be a constituent union in a food industry union in Australia; it could be one of the constituent parts in that. These amendments would facilitate that occurring. That means that all the multifaceted unions that make up the food industry would blend into one, speaking on behalf of the entire industry and giving an industry focus for Australia. That would mean that the clerks, the transport workers and those in other classifications in the food industry, including sanitary inspectors and others, could be part of one union with an industry focus, and that union could be organised along enterprise lines. That would be a big benefit to the economy if it occurred. I hope that these amendments facilitate that.

I come back to the point that the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats ordinarily would not be accepted by the Government. In the consultations we have conducted we have sought to persuade the Democrats to accept the 20,000 figure. They remain strongly wedded to their lower figure of 10,000. We recognise, though, that that would be a significant improvement upon the current provision and in those circumstances reluctantly accept the 10,000 figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night Senator Walters threw down a challenge to me but unfortunately I was engaged in ministerial business and could not be present in the chamber when she attacked my role in relation to the financial plan for the Bay View laundry in Sandy Bay. I regard Senator Walters's attack as an attempt to undermine efforts to develop a constructive long term strategy to guarantee the future of Bay View Fabricare laundry in Sandy Bay. I believe that her continuing criticism of the Government's efforts and my efforts to assist that laundry are counterproductive.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, let me tell you that, during the last election campaign, a group of concerned parents from Bay View visited my office in some distress and said that they had been attempting to get the support of the Department of Community Services and Health for some funding to overcome a crisis, a cash flow problem at Bay View, which had largely been exacerbated, though not entirely due to, the pilots dispute. I undertook to telephone the State manager of the Department and I relayed their concerns to the State manager. The State manager indicated that funding could be made available within a certain time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would be.

—Yes, would be made available within a certain time. I did not hear anything more about it. Naturally, I assumed that the matter had been dealt with. I did not regard myself as being in the old-fashioned politics of giving promises during an election campaign. I had merely helped a group of concerned parents make contact with the correct Government official. I thought no more about it. In fact, I visited Bay View Fabricare laundry at least three times between March and November including, on one occasion, a full tour of the laundry. At no stage did the management or any of those associated with Bay View mention the failure or the difficulty they had experienced in getting the funding about which we had spoken in February or March.

SPEECH.PARA: It was an absolute surprise to me when on 25 November I received a letter from the concerned parents expressing their dismay that the funding had not come through. The first I had heard about it from them was when I got that particular letter. I understand that they had contacted members of the Opposition and Senator Harradine quite independently of writing me that letter.

As soon as I became aware of their predicament, I contacted the new State manager, Mr Peter Fisher. I want to pay a tribute to Peter Fisher and to the person in the office of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), Mr Warren Gardiner, who has dealt with this matter since I brought it to their attention. It is due to their efforts that the matter of financial assistance for the laundry has now reached a satisfactory stage.

The whole basis of the approach by the Government has not been to go for a temporary quick fix to deal with the aftermath of the pilots dispute and the difficulty in retaining certain long term contracts which the laundry has lost, independently of the pilots dispute. We needed a sound business plan to help the laundry reorganise its operations on a solid footing. Senator Walters seems to favour the temporary quick fix approach. I do not.

That is why I believe the consultancy undertaken by Peat Marwick Hungerfords Management Consultants was extremely important. This particular consultancy to find a style of management, a team, which could get the laundry into a viable state cost the Government, not Bay View, $42,000. That is why a comprehensive financial report was required and a detailed strategy has emerged for overcoming Bayview's problems, thereby securing the future of the 37 disabled people who are presently employed there. That is the crucial matter on which all senators would agree as being the true focus of our concern rather than political points scoring.

The fact is that the Minister, Mr Brian Howe, yesterday approved a special payment of $45,000 to overcome immediate cash flow problems. I understand that is required to go from a Canberra trust account to Hobart and then to the organisation. This morning the management of Bay View telephoned my office quite independently to say that it was delighted with that and quite happy with the way in which it is being processed.

Further funding which will bring total assistance to a figure of not less than the $183,000 initially sought by Bay View will be paid by the end of this month in order to implement the consultants' recommendations. That is the key. The funding, at least $183,000, resulted from the recommendations of the consultants and as a result of the money being available. It may well happen that more dollars are required in order to put Bay View on to a firm financial footing. I am completely satisfied that the Department has acted responsibly and in the best interests of the employees of Bay View. I believe that we now have a sound basis for future operations of the laundry. Mr Acting Deputy President, I thank you for your support for Bay View during this period along with the support of Senator Harradine and Mr Duncan Kerr.

TALK.START.PARA: —And me?

—I do not know whether Senator Bell wrote to me. I thank those honourable senators and, as I say, the honourable member for Denison, who have supported Bay View in this matter. I believe that the attack on me last night by Senator Walters was unjustified. I believe that I have now clarified-if it needed clarification-that the amount of money sought will be available to implement the consultants' recommendations. I understand from the Bayview management that they are very happy with the stage which matters have reached.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, on the final outcome of this matter. These people had had the promise of $183,000 immediately following the election. I do not think that the Minister is at all just in saying that the subject should not have come up last night and that the promise that was made to these people should not have been carried out within the period of time mentioned rather than being delayed for nine months.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 August 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister explain the disparity which exists with respect to section 78 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which provides tax deductibility for all donations to tertiary institutions, but allows only those donations to secondary schools which are of a capital nature to be used as deductions?
(2) What was the cost to public revenue through lost revenue which resulted from the tax deductibility of donations to tertiary institutions for the financial year 1988-89?
(3) What was the cost to public revenue through lost revenue which resulted from the tax deductibility of donations to secondary schools for the financial year 1988-89?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The two types of educational institutions referred to by the Senator were added to the gift provisions at different times. The inclusion of secondary schools in 1954 was to promote the expansion of infrastructure in education facilities, to assist in the advancement of learning in Australia. The Government would have reservations about widening the scope for tax deductibility of donations for schools as this would have the potential to bias Government support for primary and secondary education, through tax revenue forgone, in favour of the wealthy and at the expense of those not so well off. For this and other reasons the Government prefers to provide its support for schools through the expenditure side of the Budget.

(2) Statistics of gifts allowed in income tax returns of individual taxpayers are classified into gifts to organisations and charities which provide assistance in Australia, overseas aid funds and approved school building funds. Gifts to tertiary institutions are included with other gifts in the category of gifts which give help in Australia. As statistics of gifts allowed in this category do not separately identify the various organisations and charities to which the gifts are provided it is not possible to provide an estimate of the revenue cost resulting from the tax deductibility of donations to tertiary institutions.

(3) Allowable gifts to schools and colleges are of a capital nature and as such are recorded for statistical purposes as gifts to approved building funds. Separate information is not available for gifts to secondary schools. As complete details of gifts allowed are not available from income tax returns for the year ended 30 June 1989 estimates have been prepared from 1987-88 data, the latest year for which complete information is available. Based on information included in income tax returns for the year ended 30 June 1988 the revenue lost from the tax deductibility of donations to schools and colleges is estimated to be $32 million.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Programs for Potential Staff

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: What amounts were spent: (a) in the financial year 1988-89; and (b) in the financial year 1989-90; on any and what types of training programs for actual or potential DSS staff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The estimated total costs of providing training are:

These estimated costs include salaries of trainers and trainees, purchase of and development of training courses, materials and equipment, accommodation costs for training venues and administrative costs.
Training courses cover induction, supervision, management, client services, personal development, ADP and client program entitlement.
The Department does not maintain detailed centralised records of all training activities in a form which allows it to identify the amount spent on each of its training programs.
As has been the practice of previous Governments, I am not prepared to authorise the use of the considerable resources that would be involved in assembling the information requested.
Training is not provided to potential DSS staff members.
